talk.start.para: —I inform the Senate that the Governor-General has this day accepted the resignations of Mr MacKellar as Minister for Health and Mr Moore as Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. Mr N. A. Brown has been appointed Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and Senator Peter Baume Minister for Health until such time as permanent appointments are made. The appointments are in addition to their present portfolios.

speech.para: I also inform the Senate that the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) resigned as Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party with effect from 8 April. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) was elected as Deputy Leader on that day.

The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) left Australia yesterday to travel to Wellington for ministerial discussions concerning closer economic relations between Australia and New Zealand. The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) is acting as Minister for Trade and Resources until Mr Anthony returns. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) left Australia yesterday to attend a meeting of the South Pacific Regional Civil Aviation and Shipping Council in the Cook Islands. The Minister for Education ( Mr Fife) is acting as Minister for Transport until Mr Hunt returns. I also inform the Senate that Senator Chaney left Australia on 8 April for discussions related to his portfolio. Senator Baume is acting as Minister for Social Security until Senator Chaney returns from overseas on 24 April. In relation to those portfolios normally represented in the Senate by Senator Chaney, I will answer questions relating to industry and commerce, Senator Durack those relating to industrial relations and Senator Messner those relating to primary industry.

speech.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talker.name: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —by leave-With regard to the ministerial resignations, I propose to table all relevant documents from the files which relate to these matters within a matter of minutes. I had hoped that they would be here. There has been some minor delay . As soon as they are available I will table them.
—They are there.

—For the information of the Senate I table documents from the official files which relate to the Honourable M. J. R. MacKellar and the Honourable John Moore in respect of Customs procedures. Accompanying these documents is a paper setting out in more legible form the handwritten annotations on documents. I will make those available immediately to the Acting Leader of the Opposition, Senator Grimes.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the papers and the statement.

I move the motion at this unusual time because of the unusual circumstances. What we have, in fact, had is a bland statement of ministerial rearrangements, no explanation and, tabled at the last minute, some accompanying documents referring apparently to the resignation of two Ministers of the Government. The matter which lies behind the resignation of the two Ministers goes beyond the private concern of the Government, as is evidenced by the Press and public comment on this matter in recent weeks. It is for this reason that I wish the Senate to have the opportunity now and at a later time, I hope, to examine it more closely.

Several crucial points arise out of the resignation of two Ministers of the Crown, which deserve a full explanation in this Parliament. The Opposition insists that the Parliament and the public receive these explanations. We certainly have not done so today. We certainly have not received such explanations in the statements issued so far. This is not a simple matter. Many questions must be asked and answered. We must know in what circumstances and how a Minister of the Crown in this country can allow, for instance, a staff member to sign a legal declaration on his behalf. We have to know what a Minister of the Crown is doing by apparently making, directly or indirectly, a false declaration to the Customs authorities. We must know how it was that, when that declaration was detected as being false, in fact no action was taken. We must know whether it is true, as alleged, that officers of the Bureau of Customs were ordered to remain silent by more senior officers and carpeted in order that this instruction would be conveyed to them. We have to know who, if anybody, instructed the senior officers and what part the Minister responsible for Customs played in these proceedings, because he knew what had happened within hours of what occurred. We have to know why no action was taken from 5 October last year, when the incident occurred, until 16 April this year, when the incident hit the public through the Press. We want to know the series of events and why there was a delay in the series of events which have occurred since 16 April. We believe that this delay and the manner in which this matter was conducted reflect much and reveal much of the attitude of this Government.

We remember that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) initially dismissed this incident as being trivial. The two Ministers concerned flew to Canberra to consult and to draw up a statement. At 8 p.m. on that day they left for Fairbairn Airport to return home, but were recalled to the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and remained there until 1.35 a.m. Still no statement was made. The whole of Saturday, 17 April, was spent by the two gentlemen preparing a statement which was released at 5 p.m. At a Press conference at the time, the essential facts of the case were admitted by the Ministers concerned. Yesterday, Monday, 19 April, we were subjected to a spectacle of discussions by Ministers, by the Cabinet and by the two Ministers involved from 2 p.m. to 8 p.m. At 8 minutes past 8 last night, the resignations of the two Ministers were announced.

These two Ministers are the twentieth and twenty-first Ministers to have resigned or to have been pushed from this Government in the six years of its existence. Some of the Ministers were similarly under a cloud. I suggest that many people would think that one of them is still under a cloud. As has been said, the penalties for ministerial impropriety in this country are severe and they should be severe. I put it to honourable senators that the penalties are just, and it is equally just that we, as members of Parliament, and the public should receive a proper explanation of what has happened. Clearly, what happened in this case was that one Minister avoided the Customs provisions of this country. When detected, he was allowed to continue this avoidance. A second Minister, on being notified of this offence and being responsible for the area concerned, chose to ignore it. The Customs officers involved in this affair were , to put it crudely but clearly, stood over to avoid the affair becoming public.

For three days and at considerable public expense the Government procrastinated and sought means of protecting the offending Ministers. Only after considerable pressure from the Press and the Opposition was action taken. Rarely in this country has there been such unanimous opinion amongst the editorialists of the most conservative newspapers, and they were all condemnatory of the Government and the delay in taking action against these Ministers. Quite clearly the Ministers were in disarray and, I suggest, are in disarray. We have had leadership challenges, we have had public brawling between Ministers and we have had attempts at a cover-up while we are facing our greatest economic crisis since World War II. The public and certainly the Opposition can have no confidence in a government with such clear divisions in its ranks even at ministerial level, a government which chooses to spend such time and such money- one can think alone of the VIP aircraft left standing at Canberra Airport for that time-on exercises like this while this country needs action and good government to get over its problems.

What is the position of the Customs officers who were involved? My colleagues in another place, Mr John Brown and Mr Hayden, will be moving for an inquiry into the treatment of these Customs officers and the manner in which they were asked to cover up for ministerial indiscretions in this way. There are legal implications. I hope my colleague Senator Evans will discuss this aspect again this afternoon. But the simple fact of the matter is that this Parliament and the public of this country cannot be pushed off and fobbed off by the Minister coming in here and making a bland statement on ministerial rearrangements, with no explanation from him as to just what has gone on and what will go on in the future, and by tabling the official documents which relate to this matter. We will, of course, want to examine those documents and discuss them later but we believe that the Parliament deserves a better explanation than it has had. We believe that the country deserves better behaviour than we have had from Government Ministers in this place not only in the last few days and few months but also in the last six years.

I have moved that the Senate take note of the statement because we will need to continue this debate. I hope the House of Representatives takes note of the motion which will be moved in that place today by my colleagues. I can assure the Government and the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) that, unless we get a better explanation than we have had and unless we get the opportunity to debate this matter in the manner in which we should be able to debate it, we will take further action in this Senate in an effort to ensure that proper government is seen to be done.

It was felt by the Government that before any procedure for debate was established the documents should be tabled so that everybody would have the advantage of reading them before any debate. I give an undertaking that I would be very willing indeed to make available time for a proper debate on the whole of this matter. I simply make that clear on the basis that it seems to me that, the documents having been tabled now, some little time ought to elapse so that they can be studied. I would be very happy to schedule--
—Can you indicate when?

—I think that is a matter of judgment between the leaders of the parties so that when they feel they have had sufficient time to study the documents the debate may take place. I give a full undertaking in that regard.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: —It needs very little time for the Senate to appreciate the issues of substance and principle that are involved in the essence of the statement made here today by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick). No doubt a careful reading and canvassing of the documents that have been tabled will enable a fuller appreciation of all the sordid details of the Moore-MacKellar affair and no doubt we, as a Senate, will want to debate those sordid details further in the light of that study. Certainly, I do not wish to indicate in any way by standing to continue the debate on the motion moved by Senator Grimes that that is where we propose to leave the matter. We will, in fact, accept the Minister's offer for the debate to be brought on in Government time, either at a later hour this day or on a later day, in order that the issues might be more fully canvassed and explored than they can be at the moment.

speech.para: Nonetheless, many aspects of this matter can be the subject of an immediate response. The basic response must be that the Ministry reconstituted today, the subject matter of which is the essence of Senator Sir John Carrick's statement, is a Ministry over which there now hangs a palpable stench of decay. The Fraser Government is a government which, as this morning's Australian newspaper rather nicely put it, has suffered an attrition rate of 36 per cent since 1975 when it came into office. Such an attrition rate, incidentally, would be quite intolerable if we were talking about an aircraft or a motor car and would long since have resulted in the substitution for it of a new model.

The attrition rate has been brought about by the 16 departures from the Fraser Ministry which have occurred since 1975-departures brought about as a result of dismissal, of resignation, of what has been euphemistically described as early retirement, or of suspension. I remind the Senate that the list is an impressive roll call, involving the names of Messrs Garland, Lynch, Ellicott, Sheil, Withers, Robinson, Sinclair, Webster, Cotton, McLeay, Adermann, Staley, Groom, Peacock and now, of course, Moore and MacKellar. Fully five of those 16 were resignations, suspensions or premature departures based on circumstances of personal impropriety or apparent lack of probity arising, not out of the conduct of their ministerial portfolios, but out of their personal conduct. That was the situation governing the suspension, dismissal or resignation of Messrs Garland, Lynch, Withers, Robinson and Sinclair. As a result of this long, sorry and sordid course of events we have a government composed of people who do not deserve the confidence of either this Parliament or this nation.

We have a situation, following the roll call announced by Senator Sir John Carrick today, in which a number of obviously more competent potential Ministers are still languishing on the back benches of this Parliament-some of them, indeed, in the Senate. No doubt, among others, Senators Peter Rae, Jessop, Missen and Martin-Martin, I hasten to emphasise for the benefit of an honourable senator on the Government side-will not mind my mentioning their names in this context. Those sorts of people with their sorts of competence remain languishing on the back bench while those with thicker hides or those with more political muscle, such as the flameproof Mr Sinclair and his friends, sit it out imperturbably, prepared to wear allegations of impropriety and substantial conclusions of impropriety-for example, those brought down by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in the case of Mr Sinclair-while being at the same time prepared to pass judgment, as they did yesterday, on their colleagues Moore and MacKellar. What hypocrisy there was in the unanimity with which the Cabinet yesterday apparently voted on this matter, given some of the people there. There is a stench in the air. It is a stench which will certainly remain in the air as long as a number of the bodies lying around in this Ministry remain unburied.

The theme of propriety and integrity in government has been constantly reiterated by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), nowhere perhaps more cogently and forcefully than in his electorate talk, subsequently widely publicised, on 12 March 1978 when he said:
One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore the integrity and honesty of government.
Without integrity-without the appearance and reality of integrity-no government can hope to have the confidence of the people, or the trust of the people.
We were determined-
Perhaps the use of the past tense is more significant than at first sight appears-

to restore Australians' faith in their national Government-and in the process of government. From the beginning, the Government desired to re-establish the absolute propriety and unquestioned integrity that were a hallmark--
So he said-
of the Menzies years in Australia.

That was the promise. What has the performance been? The gulf between the promise and the performance has been spectacular, perhaps nowhere more so than in the course of events which underlie the resignations, unfortunate as they may have been from the point of view of the individuals concerned, of Messrs Moore and MacKellar yesterday. There was the initial behaviour of Mr MacKellar in that Customs queue, at the very least behaviour which was arrogant and foolish. At the worst it was something much worse than that. It was behaviour which was seriously criminal under provisions of the Customs Act and possibly also under provisions of the Crimes Act.

The question of the criminality or otherwise of the behaviour of Mr MacKellar and the other characters in the cast is not something which we would wish to pursue now. Penalties have been paid, and paid at a very significant price, by the Ministers concerned as a result of yesterday's events. But the point in referring again, as we have previously, to those criminal offences which may well have been committed by the gentlemen involved-in various combinations of them-is to indicate what must have been apparent to all the parties involved, and that is the gravity, the seriousness and the inherent non-triviality of what was involved in the circumstances. So we had the initial behaviour of Mr MacKellar. We then had the subsequent behaviour of Mr MacKellar who, a few days later we are told-it is now on the public record-wrote a letter to his Minister, Mr Moore, offering to pay the relevant duty and, indeed, to pay the penalty duty . But that letter was not accompanied by any cheque for the amount in question and it was all too obviously rather a reverse of what lawyers tend to refer to as an invitation to treat. It was an invitation perhaps to do the converse of that.

talk.start.para: —The letter requested how much duty was to be paid.

—That may be so and maybe that is one of the points of detail that can, in fact, be better discussed and better resolved at a later stage of this debate. Further, of course, there was the question of the initial behaviour of Mr Moore who refused to act, who refused to apply the law when the situation was brought to his attention, apparently initially orally and later in writing, exercising in the process a so-called discretion to waive the application of the penalty duty which is a course simply not allowed to him under the statute law as it presently stands. Should the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, be willing in Question Time or at any other time and place to deny the legitimacy of that legal conclusion I would be only too happy to hear from him. Following the behaviour of Mr Moore on that occasion there was associated with it the behaviour of Mr Moore's Department and his Customs officers who were either not asking themselves the right questions on a different view of the facts, or not giving the Minister the full information. Alternatively, at the very least, on yet another view of the facts they were simultaneously engaged in endeavouring to cover up the possible commission of an offence and to cover up in the process the complaints that were being made by junior officials. That, as Senator Grimes has said, will be the subject matter, we believe, of debate in another place.

speech.para: There was the behaviour in concert of Messrs Moore and MacKellar who, we are told, spent something like 18 hours putting together an account of what happened which should have taken them no more than about half an hour if the facts were as clear cut, if their moral guilt, as distinct perhaps from technical guilt, was as doubtful as has been indicated in the text of that statement when it finally did appear some two days after the issue was first set in running. As we further explore the gulf between promise and performance on this question of probity and propriety, there has been the attitude of the Prime Minister, the fount of all probity and all propriety so far as this Government is concerned. He is a Prime Minister who, to the Press through his own private staff, and to the public through the Press, made it clear that his own initial reaction was that this was no more than a bit of minor aberrant misbehaviour by the Ministers in question and could be regarded as essentially a peccadillo of the kind that would be appropriately dealt with by a slap on the hand. But this was a position on the part of the Prime Minister which was manifestly utterly inconsistent with the gravity of the situation as must have been apparent to him by Friday evening on even the most cursory examination of the relevant law and the relevant material before him.

Then there was the attitude of the Cabinet which once again did not react as quickly as one would have thought it inevitably had to when the matter finally came before it yesterday. It was a Cabinet which took fully five hours to reach what obviously was the only possible decision that could be made by any government anxious to preserve any shred of credibility.

This is a government which will not do the right thing because it is the right thing. It will do the right thing only because it is forced into acting in that way. It will do the right thing-it will seek to pay the price that must be exacted for doing the wrong thing-only when it is caught, as it were, in flagrante delicto. Here the only reason the right thing was ultimately done, the only reason any steps were taken to preserve any shred of credibility of the Westminster conventions of ministerial resignation, was that the Government was exposed in the course of action in which it, through the misbehaviour and foolish behaviour of its Ministers, had become involved.

It was not as a result of any commitment to probity or propriety on the part of the Prime Minister or any one of his senior Ministers, including the senior Minister sitting in here today, that this course of events took place. It was a result of, first, the exposure of the affair by unhappy junior Customs officers; secondly, the running of the story in the Australian newspaper last Friday; thirdly, the naming of the hitherto unnamed Minister by the Australian Labor Party through our spokesman, John Brown, on Friday; and finally, of course, the universal editorial condemnation of the situation by the whole of the nation's Press yesterday morning.

So this is a Ministry, the recomposition of which was announced to us today, which is being constructed now, as it has been from the outset, entirely on the wrong principles. It is a Ministry which was put together on a basis which has nothing to do with the quality and the competence of the individual members of it, as undoubtedly will be testified to by only too many honourable senators sitting on the opposite side of this chamber. It is a Ministry which has been constituted on a basis which has nothing to do with the best interests of this nation. Rather, it has everything to do with serving the selfish demands and preoccupations of the National Party in this nation. It is a Ministry the composition of which has everything to do with preserving the Prime Minister's own narrow-extremely narrow-personal and ideological power base within his party . It is a Ministry which, so constructed, is increasingly obviously out of touch with the needs of this nation and, as was demonstrated by the affairs of the last week or so, increasingly out of touch with the wishes, the desires and the needs of his own political party.

We are confronted in this Ministry with a shaking, tottering edifice. One of the reasons that this Ministry-this Government- is so shaking and so tottering is that it is rotten at the core and it remains rotten at the core notwithstanding the latest round in this long history of purges to which this once proud party has been subjecting itself during the whole lifetime of this Ministry. There is no way that probity, propriety and integrity in government will be restored in this nation by just one or two further changes being made to the composition of this Ministry, by one or two more purges of the kind that have occurred with monotonous regularity since 1975. The only way that probity, integrity and propriety in government will be returned in Australia is by throwing out the whole lot of this Ministry and replacing it with an Australian Labor Party government.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Button, I present the following petition from 14 citizens of Australia:

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That since 1788 discrimination has existed in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference.

That since 1788 such discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons in the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of accommodation and the provision of goods and services under Commonwealth jurisdiction and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

talk.start.para: —I present the following petition from 152 citizens of Australia:

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Northern Territory of Australia respectfully showeth:

The level of home ownership in Australia is falling as increasing costs, particularly interest rates on housing loans, continue to rise. High interest rates and the increasing difficulties in obtaining housing loan finance have combined to jeopardise the prospects for home ownership of many Australians.
Firm and positive action must be taken by the Federal Government to reduce interest rates on housing loans.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
The Government will initiate policies to lower interest rates on home loans and promote greater availability of finance for housing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

talk.start.para: —I present the following petition from 106 citizens of Australia :

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown; convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened, humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to-
(1) reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or marriage
(3) protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

talk.start.para: —I present the following petition from 19 citizens of Australia:

speech.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade postal and mail services throughout Australia will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by:
Downgrading a large number of official post offices;
Reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
Reducing the number of street posting boxes;
Delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
Downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
Using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Goverment will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the postal and mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Quality of Television Programs
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That some television stations throughout Australia are taking advantage of the absence of ratings surveys during the Christmas-New Year holiday season to broadcast inferior quality programs and innumerable repeats.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will undertake and publish the results of ratings surveys during holiday periods to encourage the broadcasting of quality TV programs at those times.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Pensioner Benefits
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised- that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profitting from Australia' s mineral wealth, whilst, pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing. Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. All pension and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973. Reintroduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $ 200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Anti-discrimination Legislation
petition.para: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, pregnancy, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference is a fundamental human right, and

That it is both the duty and responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society's inability to provide full paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, or pregnancy.

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) Restore objective tests of irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

petition.title: Sex Discrimination Bill 1981
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantages in employment, education , accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment;
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Child Care Expenses: Tax Deductibility
petition.para: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Family Law Act
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown,
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .

petition.title: Plant Variety Rights
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public respect for the Government and the institution of parliament is diminished by the non-disclosure of pecuniary interests of Ministers of the Government.

That on August 2nd 1979, the Minister for Communications announced through the Parliamentary Press Gallery that he had agreed to repay in 3 instalments of $100 ,000 at 10 percent interest the sum of $300,000 which had been misappropriated.

Your petitioners call upon the Senate to take steps to implement the recommendations on disclosure of the Joint Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament, 1975, agreed to by Committee members of all political parties.

In particular, your petitioners call upon the Senate to restore respect for the Parliamentary system by seeking a declaration from the Minister for Communications as to whether he has made the $100,000 repayment due on February 1st 1982.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Interest Rates
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we request that the Government take immediate steps to relieve the burden of increased mortage costs resulting from increasing home loan interest rates.

We find that the resultant increases in mortage payments have unduly caused a reduction in the standard of living, reflected in the severe difficulty experienced in meeting household budgetary commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Maintain Government regulation of bank interest rates.
2. Amend the relevant Acts to provide for a mortgage payment subsidy scheme, based on a 'needs' requirement.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
