question.speaker: McLaren Sen G.T.

talk.start.para: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, refers to the stream of recent statements from Government Ministers deploring the false expectations raised by people talking up the resources boom. I now ask the Minister: Does he regard himself as an offender? In October 1980, just before the election, he stated:

question.para: Rundle now promises that in four years time, on stream will be 20,000 barrels a day, by eight years time 200,000 barrels a day, equivalent to what we are importing at this moment.
I further ask the Minister: What are the current status of, and prospects for, Rundle?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I do not believe that there were significantly false expectations of a resources boom. If there were, the main offender is the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, who has issued statements saying that the amount of expenditure on resources development in New South Wales alone was $24.5 billion-that has been said in the course of the last year-whereas the Commonwealth as a whole has indicated something in the order of only $32 billion. Quite clearly, if the expectations are to be measured, they are to be measured in the first place as to the credibility or otherwise of Mr Wran's statements. I do not believe that any statement of mine was aimed at talking up the resources boom.

answer.para: That can be tested very simply. Upon my discovery that there were differences between the partners of Rundle as to what might be the expectations I informed the Prime Minister and, as a result, the Treasurer and I approached the Rundle partners and brought about a situation in which a modified statement was made. My task as a Minister is aimed at presenting the accurate situation to the people of Australia. It was believed, as stated by the Rundle partners, that they had particular expectations at that time, for a variety of reasons that have now become known. One of those reasons was that certain defects were discovered in the mining area and the nature of the materials that were there would have constituted a mining wall which would have created further difficulties. Another reason, I have no doubt, was that the immediacy of the oil price rises had receded slightly. The Rundle process was altered so that the first three or four-year phase is to be done off-shore in America by tests of retorts and pilot plants. A subsequent phase will be undertaken here. Emphatically, it has not been my task to give other than the most accurate information available to the public. The test of that is that as soon as I became knowledgeable that, in fact, what was being represented to the public might not be right, I acted to make sure that that was corrected.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that my question had nothing to do with Mr Wran but with himself and statements he made about Rundle. In view of what the Minister has just said, I ask him: What was the lapse of time between the Minister learning that there was a difference between the Rundle partners and the Minister making the public statements to which he just now referred?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I would need to look at the timetable to give a precise answer. My recollection is that I went to Gladstone to look at a whole series of developments. In the course of that I asked for and was given an update on Rundle. I discovered that the situation, as given to me, was different from the public perception. I came back and immediately reported that to the Prime Minister. We immediately set in train contact with the two partners. We made a request stressing that there should be urgently a reconciliation between the two partners as to facts so that there should be presentation of that information as quickly as possible. That was done. I am not sure of the exact number of days or the exact number of weeks. That can be readily ascertained. The facts, as soon as they were technically available, were made available.

—My question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs relates to representations that I have received regarding the condition of the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital in Western Australia. Is the Minister aware that the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Public Works has approved plans for the construction of new operating theatres and two specialty wards? Will the Minister explain to the Senate why these works have been delayed and when he expects the works to be completed?

—It is true that the decision on the future of the Hollywood Repatriation Hospital redevelopment has been in gestation for quite some considerable time. In fact, the original reference, I think, was made back in July 1979. Since then the matter has been considered by the Public Works Committee. On its report becoming known to the Government in about September 1980, there was some further delay while certain propositions were put to the Federal Government by the Western Australian Government and also while there was reconsideration of the whole principle of repatriation hospitals which was undertaken by the Government in the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions report. Since then there has been a further reconsideration of the matter by the Public Works Committee. I understand that very soon the Committee will be in a position to report to the Parliament as to the future of that development. We await that with a great deal of interest. Providing that report arrives in very quick time I will take the matter to the Budget Cabinet this year. I hope that we will be able to obtain funds for the development.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Has the Minister had his attention drawn to an article in the Weekend Australian entitled ' ''Butcher of Java'' ends Australian indoctrination tour'? What was the purpose of the visit of Lieutenant-General Sarwo Ehdie Wibowo as declared on his application for a visa? Are any of the students addressed by the former military leader in receipt of financial or other assistance from the Australian Government? What assistance was given by Australian universities in this project?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I did see the article. I do not have the information sought by Senator Robertson but I will get it in detail and let him have it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the Department of Foreign Affairs keep the Minister continuously informed of the degree of preparations by the Argentinians preceding the attack on the Falkland Islands? Further, did the Australian authorities inform the Government of the United Kingdom about the gravity of the situation?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I will need to refer to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to ascertain precisely what information was provided to him and the direct communications that he may have had with the United Kingdom Government. I think the attitude of the Australian Government has been made clear with regard to the Argentine invasion of the Falkland Islands. Statements were made early in April by the Prime Minister and the Acting Foreign Minister condemning the Argentine action and expressing support for the British Government. I will see whether I can obtain some early advice with regard to the specific matters to which Senator Watson referred.

—I ask the Minister for Finance a question concerning the state of the economy. Does she agree that politicians of all parties, trade union leaders and certainly editors of 'prestigious' financial newspapers, while retaining the right to be critical, should act and speak with a sense of responsibility and a knowledge of the damage which sensational statements prophesying depression can do to the present delicate state of the economy? However, will the Minister agree that, compared with when the Government took office, inflation and unemployment are up, interest rates are at an all time high and rising, personal taxes are at an unprecedented level, people are queueing for emergency relief and tax avoidance is rife? In view of these facts, will the Minister agree that the old solutions being tried by the Government simply do not work any more and that the Government is deluding itself if it believes, as several of its spokesmen say, that the only problem is to improve its communications? In particular, is the Government prepared to consider a $500m increase in the Budget deficit to stimulate activity in the housing industry, the small business sector and community services? Further, will the Minister agree that industrial relations can be used either as a blunt political weapon to score cheap political points or as a most valuable economic tool to negotiate with trade unions to withhold unreasonable wage demands in exchange for a reduction in taxes or other benefits?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —Senator Chipp has raised a many faceted question which draws attention to many of the matters that are of current concern both to the Government and to the people of Australia. In the early part of the question he referred to the public comments of television commentators and editors of financial and other newspapers. I think it is fair to say that in more recent days or weeks there has been a tendency to be alarmist about the state of the Australian economy, instead of looking at its strengths and at the very positive factors that exist for the people of this country. For instance, when talking about the number of projects that are set to go ahead in the development of our resources, one finds great controversy because some projects worth $2 billion are not to proceed. People should look instead at the projects worth over $30 billion that are to proceed. Sometimes we should approach things with optimism rather than pessimism.

answer.para: Senator Chipp mentioned inflation, unemployment, personal taxes and other individual aspects of the economy. Perhaps they ought to be subjected to more detailed comments than would be appropriate at Question Time. I have figures, for instance, on the activity in the housing industry which compare the lending approvals to individuals for housing by the major lenders. These figures show that in the three months to February 1982 approvals rose by 3.4 per cent compared with the three months to November 1981, and were 12.8 per cent below the level in the three months to February 1981. So one could be comparing figures which show a drop or one could be looking at figures which show a tendency to increase. Very often it is the period that one chooses for comparison that can become important.

As far as the matter of industrial relations is concerned, I do think that what Senator Chipp has implied in his question is very important; that is, that it ought not to be simply a matter of controversy between the arms of government or employers and trade union movements to score cheap points from one another but rather that they ought to seek a way of working together in the interests of all . I am sure there are those in the trade union movement who are aware that the claims they make for changes in their own conditions or in their wage structures do have an adverse effect on those who are seeking employment opportunities.

Again, if we are to look at the figures that would reveal exactly what is happening, perhaps we ought to look at the seasonally adjusted data I have before me which reveal that employment increased by 1.2 per cent over the year to February 1982 which compares with a 2.4 per cent increase over the year to February 1981. In February employment fell by 0.1 per cent and in the three months to February employment fell by 0.1 per cent. I think it has been stated that the level of employment has been relatively flat this financial year, increasing by 0.4 per cent between June 1981 and February 1982. There are other figures which show the way in which full time employment has increased.

If honourable senators look at the various sectors of full time, part time, male and female employment and so on they will see that these statistics are all relevant to the sort of question that has been raised by Senator Chipp. However, as his question related to industrial relations, I do think that it is appropriate that we should be working together to seek the way in which we are able to maximise employment opportunities and the structure of wages that can be paid to benefit all Australians.

The other matter raised by Senator Chipp concerned interest rates. Here again we compare sometimes favourably and sometimes unfavourably with other countries. Schedules that I have for March 1982 show that with regard to the 180-day bank commercial bill rate Australia has around a 20 per cent rate compared with 16.5 per cent for the United States of America, 14.5 per cent for the United Kingdom, 13 per cent for West Germany and 16.5 per cent for Canada. So one does find relativities in other comparable countries. I take up the spirit of Senator Chipp's question by saying that it would be very timely for Australians to look at many of the statistics, to analyse the problems and the strengths within the Australian economy and to seek to work together to present the best opportunities in the coming year.

There was a proposal in the question with regard to a $500m addition to the deficit. Perhaps it is not unknown to honourable senators that this Budget will show a substantial increase in the deficit over what was forecast at the time the Budget was introduced last year. Perhaps those who during the year have been suggesting that there ought to be some increase in the deficit have not taken into account the fact that there has been an increase in the deficit and that it has not had the result that would have been predicted if we had been talking about, for instance, a $1 billion deficit at the time we cast the Budget last year. So these things do need to be measured at different times. As we are now entering a pre-Budget consultative process, I think the question of whether a $ 500m deficit would be the appropriate way in which to increase assistance to housing or to small business or whatever, would be better left not discussed by me at this time.

What has also been implied in the question is that it may be said that there is just a breakdown in the communication of Government policy, and that that is the problem. I would never argue that if a policy is wrong good communications will have a positive effect. Equally, I would possibly argue that if a policy is right its effect will be self-evident. Perhaps much could be done in communicating with the Australian people to gain for them a better understanding of the economy. I think this could be shared by all of us in this place and by those who are the mass communicators through the media of this country. However, if we have the opportunity at any time to discuss in more detail some of the facets of the Australian economy, I think there are very relevant statistics that could well be explained to the Australian people to give them a better understanding of the problems and the underlying strengths.

talk.start.para: —I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to a report from Great Britain of a process whereby heating oil can be recovered from waste lubricating oil. Is the Minister able to advise the Senate how much heating oil is used and how much waste lubricating oil is dumped each year in Australia? Can the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council look into the relevance and viability of such a process being introduced into Australia in the hope of making Australia more energy independent?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —The question of the recycling of waste oil is one that has been before me and my Department for quite some time. One of the actions taken was to conduct a survey to inquire into the disposal of used lubricating oil and to assess what potential exists for arranging the economic collection of the available oil that is not currently being collected. That survey was conducted last year by the Morgan (Roy) Research Centre Pty Ltd on behalf of my Department. According to that survey 162,190 kilolitres of used oil were potentially available for collection and recycling in 1980. Of this amount, 87, 355 kilolitres are currently being re-used or recycled in some way.
—Great. A question without notice! That is terrific. You are getting back to your old form. Why don't you put it on notice and give the rest of us a go?

—The question of waste oil disposal is one that comes within my brief. That leaves some 74,800 kilolitres unaccounted for. The waste oil that is being re-used is in the main being blended with fuel oil for subsequent burning as fuel. When used in this way the full energy value of the oil is recovered. Used lubricating oil can also be re-refined to produce a lubricant as good as the virgin lubricating oil from which it is derived. One such refiner is currently operating in the Sydney area. The major problem facing greater use of the resource in this way is that of guaranteeing adequate supplies of used oil of a consistent quality. One of the problems is that oil is now sold through supermarkets for oil changing at home and it is very hard to collect the waste. Other uses for waste oil are spraying roads for dust, marking sports grounds and preserving timber fences. The matter is an important one. I will provide further detailed information to the honourable senator and arrange for its inclusion in Hansard.

question.speaker: Sibraa Sen K.W.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer provide reliable and up to date figures regarding the amount of foreign investment in Australian rural land, estimated conservatively at $240m between April 1976 and June 1981 by the Foreign Investment Review Board? I ask whether the situation now is the same as that described in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald in January which stated:

question.para: There is so little reliable information on foreign investment in Australian industry and land that when Federal Cabinet came to decide on Tuesday to seek greater local ownership, it did not know what the existing level was.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I realise that there is some difficulty in being precise with regard to figures. I do not know whether further information on this matter has become available in more recent months from the Treasury or from the Foreign Investment Review Board. If it has I will see what may be provided and what response the Treasurer has to make with regard to the availability and accuracy of such statistics. I will see what information can be provided as soon as possible.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Education noted an item appearing in the Saturday 17 April edition of the Sydney Morning Herald under the title 'Strings wanted on State aid' in which it is alleged that a New South Wales Australian Labor Party platform committee has recommended that all private schools receiving State aid should be made to account publicly for the way they spend the funds received from State and private sources? Can the Minister inform the Senate what provisions exist, if any, for the public schools funded by Federal funds to account for the way in which they spend their funds and whether the public is in any way informed of the way this is being done?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I saw the article in the Press. I have always wondered why some of our political opponents should want to be hypercritical about the non-government schools. The fact is that in the Schools Commission reports the non-government schools have been shown to have levels of amenities and assets much below those of the State schools. The Schools Commission has consistently recommended that the amenities and assets should be lifted and put to better use . The Schools Commission has a strong overview of the non-government school sector and it is conscious that the money being applied to that sector is not being wasted but, in fact, that some 80 per cent or 90 per cent of the non- government schools have levels of amenities and general conditions well below those of the State schools. So I fear that any pressure upon the non-government schools is grossly misdirected. Incidentally, the general public is exercising its freedom of choice and more members of the general public are now moving towards the non-government schools. The methods of accountability for the State schools would vary in the various States. I would need to seek that information and make it available to the honourable senator.

—Will the Minister representing the Prime Minister ask the Prime Minister to explain what standards of propriety are required of Ministers in this Government? Will he confirm that authorising discretionary payments to a company in which a Minister is a shareholder-as Mr Nixon did in clear breach of the Bowen rules which are supposed to have been accepted by this Government-is acceptable? Will he confirm that retaining possession of $300,000 acknowledged to have been misappropriated-as Mr Sinclair did-is acceptable but that evading import duty on a television set is not?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —As always Senator Walsh takes liberties with the facts in stating these matters. As to the first matter, the Prime Minister has stated the standards he expects from his Ministers. Not only does he expect them but also he demands and receives them. Indeed, the actions of the two Ministers yesterday are in accordance with the Westminster standards. The standards required by the Prime Minister are those which, in the Westminster system, are regarded as being of the highest ethics and being standards more rigid than those demanded of others. I have repeated in this place before that the matter with regard to Mr Nixon concerns a minor shareholding in a primary industry co- operative. In other words, if one is a farmer and one markets through a co- operative one holds some nominal shares in that co-operative from which one only gets the benefit, as I understand it, in that the co-operative does the handling and the marketing. Everybody knows that that is a basic principle within the rural community. Everybody knows that it is not in the true sense a pecuniary interest in that the shares are talked up in value or anything of that nature. Also, everybody knows that Mr Nixon, by his actions, penalised the co-operative and made a decision against the co-operative; so it would be good to look at the other side of the moon.

answer.para: As to the third statement, which no doubt relates to Mr Sinclair, let us put the record straight. Mr Sinclair is not guilty in any way of any misappropriation. The courts of the land found that, and it is up to every member of this Senate to uphold that finding because it is the rule of law. It is a sad fact that Mr Sinclair's father apparently misappropriated some funds, and it has been the sad duty of Mr Sinclair to face the situation. On his own statement, he is setting about to make repayments of those moneys. There is no reflection at all on Mr Sinclair in this matter, and the courts of the land have said that. I want to make it clear that in the continual raising of these matters there is no reflection at all upon the standards of conduct of those Ministers, and indeed, in the latter case, a court of law said so.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Do the Bowen guidelines say that a Minister in a position to make discretionary payments to a company in which he is a shareholder must either resign or call in another Minister to take over his functions for that purpose? Did Mr Sinclair acknowledge that he retained possession of $300,000 which he stated his father misappropriated? If so, will he-that is, Senator Carrick-specify the liberties he alleged I took with the facts in my original question?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I need to look at the Bowen guidelines to see exactly whether the question as posed is accurate. I will look at them and respond. I repeat the circumstances of Mr Sinclair: A member of Mr Sinclair's family committed an offence. A court of law--
—Misappropriated money, $100,000 of which he still has, on his own admission.
—A court of law said that Mr Sinclair was not guilty of any offence at all.
—The court said he was not guilty of forgery and a few other things. It did not say he did not have the stolen money.

—All the charges that were levelled against Mr Sinclair were found not to be correct. Mr Sinclair was totally acquitted of those charges . There is no suggestion at law, except by the continual innuendoes. It is an offence against the Standing Orders in this place for an honourable member to allege impropriety against a member of the Parliament. I repeat: The court of law found that there was no case for Mr Sinclair to answer, and therefore there is no question at all of impropriety.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noticed recent claims by the insurance industry that deliberately lit fires, motivated by criminal intent, conservatively cost all who are obliged to pay the consequential additional insurance premiums in excess of $200m per annum? Should not an awareness of this huge, growing and often undetected criminal area encourage both State and Federal governments to pay more attention to arson investigation? Is it a fact that the majority of the States do not yet possess their own arson squads, and those which do exist are undermanned so that many fires are not investigated with the desirable degree of expertise required or may not be investigated at all?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —As I understand it, matters involving suspected fraud or arson that come to the notice of the insurance industry would be matters which it would seem appropriate to refer to the State authority concerned. I am not totally aware of the facts with regard to the arson squads that exist in the various States. However, if there is any information that the Treasurer could provide on it, I will see that Senator Archer is advised. I do think that the matters that he raises will, in most instances, primarily be matters for State governments.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the extent and seriousness of the problem, and the fact that the States have not controlled it, will the Minister request the Treasurer to consider the establishment of, and Federal Government participation in, a total investigation of the matter with the States and the industry?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —I have no problem in referring the matter to the Treasurer for his consideration. Whether he would consider it appropriate for the initiative to come from him, or whether it is something in which State Premiers or State Treasurers would feel that they would have the initiative, is a matter of delicate balance. However, I can only draw the attention of the Treasurer to the two questions and see whether there is any response from him on this matter, which undoubtedly is one of fairly substantial proportions.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It is a fact that his Department is responsible for funding the national trachoma program? Has the Minister seen a statement by the Queensland Premier this morning that reintroduction of a trachoma and eye health program for Queensland Aboriginals would depend on the political affiliations of the program's officials concerned? Can the Minister advise when it became necessary in Australia to have specific political views before one is permitted to undertake vital work in government funded programs of this sort?

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —Senator Georges asks whether the Department of Aboriginal Affairs administers the national trachoma program. The answer is that it does not. We do have an interest, through the Aboriginal public health improvement program, in attending to some of those matters which were mentioned in the report of the program such as water, sewerage and other matters. Those are the responsibility of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
—Who is funding the program now?

—I will come to that point. We are funding a number of those programs through the Aboriginal public health improvement program. I remind the Senate that we have committed $50m to that program to improve water and sewerage . It was pointed out by the national trachoma and eye health program that this was an important way of approaching that problem. The control of that program is carried out by the Department of Health. Until this morning I could have referred the question to the Minister for Health.

answer.para: I understand, in relation to that part of the program which is administered by the Department of Health, that the Department has been waiting upon detailed submissions from the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists. Honourable senators will recall that the program was the result of an investigation in the first place by the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists which developed a pilot program which was then implemented in different States and which had the purposes both of survey and of some prescriptive efforts to try to carry out treatment.

talk.start.para: —Who funded that?

—The Department of Health has had the funding of the trachoma program. It has been held up while the College of Ophthalmologists has been developing and presenting some proposals for the continuation of the program. The College has determined that the program should be carried on through State controlled committees rather than through a committee under a single national control. That is the wish of the College. I think honourable senators will understand that I have not yet had time to check with my new Department as to where that matter stands.

answer.para: Senator Georges then asked about a newspaper statement which he saw today and which is attributed to the Premier of Queensland. I have not seen that report. If I understood Senator Georges's question, it is that the Premier has said that he would be interested in the political affiliations of those working in the program. I would be interested, first of all, in the motivation of those working in the program to ensure that they were determined to stamp out trachoma and to carry out the treatment of those with trachoma. It has not been the practice, certainly with moneys that I have granted through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, to ask any questions about people's political affiliations. We are interested in the programs to which they are directing their efforts. I would be very interested in testing the proposals now before the Department of Health against the points which Senator Georges raised. On the other hand, I hope that those who took money to treat trachoma would not see that money as money which could be used to mount what were political programs not directed towards the primary purpose of health care and eye care.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to allegations made by the Australian musician, Roger Woodward, on Nationwide last night that he had been threatened personally by employees of the Soviet Embassy in Australia, that the Polish Ambassador, His Excellency Mr Frackiewicz, is not accredited by the present regime in Poland, and that his staff comprise 'thugs employed terrorising Australian citizens of Polish descent'. I ask: Are these allegations being investigated? If not, will they be investigated? Is the Polish Ambassador, Mr Frackiewicz, accedited by the present regime in Poland? What precedent is there for ambassadors remaining in office in Australia after the overthrow of their accrediting government? Will the Government remind the ambassadors of the Soviet Union and Poland of their obligations to ensure that none of their staff enjoying diplomatic status abuse the privileges accorded to them in this country.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —I have some information from the Minister for Foreign Affairs on this matter. I am not sure whether it deals with all the questions raised by Senator Lewis. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has been informed of allegations made by the Australian pianist, Mr Roger Woodward, on Nationwide on 19 April. He understands that Mr Woodward made similar allegations in the Sydney Press in mid-February. Mr Woodward has now advised the Minister for Administrative Services of those allegations and they have been referred to the Australian Federal Police. The behaviour of foreign missions and their personnel in Australia is subject to well-established conventions which the Government is committed to uphold.

answer.para: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has pointed out that the Polish Ambassador in Australia is, in fact, the representative of the Polish head of state. In that regard his credentials would not have been affected by the imposition of martial law in Poland. The formality of the Ambassador's accreditation to Australia is to be seen separately from the Australian Government's attitude towards the current martial law government in Poland. The Australian Government has condemned martial law in unequivocal terms. It has made its views clear to the martial law authorities now in power in Warsaw. If there are any other comments that the Minister for Foreign Affairs wishes to make on Senator Lewis's question I will see that Senator Lewis is advised.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. Given that the preliminary Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for March show that approximately 6.7 per cent of the work force is now registered as unemployed, will the Government agree that the situation is getting out of hand and that a constructive program to correct it should be implemented immediately? Has the Minister received a suggestion from the Ecumenical Unemployment Task Group that a committee including representatives of employers, trade unions, welfare groups, churches, government members and unemployed people should be set up for a community inquiry into unemployment and its effects on society similar to the Commission of Inquiry into Poverty. Does the Government view this as a constructive suggestion? Would it be prepared to establish such an inquiry and allocate resources and funds to it?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I understand that the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has received such a suggestion from the Ecumenical Unemployment Task Group. The Minister is of the view at present that it is not appropriate to have an inquiry along the lines that were outlined in the suggestion. I think in the mind of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs the committee that would be set up, as suggested by the Ecumenical Group, would be nothing more than a diversion from tackling the problem. The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs and the Government have been active in tackling the problem. I think the manpower and training programs that have been implemented by the Government have been helpful and are working to provide wider training and employment opportunities. On behalf of the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs my response to that suggestion is that he is not of the view at present that an inquiry along those lines would assist in a problem which has already been identified as one of serious proportions and one which is being tackled through a diversity of training and other programs which he believes are working well.

—In light of the events in recent days, can the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs inform the Senate what guidelines, if any, are given to Customs officers for the treatment of Federal Ministers at their point of re-entry to Australia? By way of explanation I refer to Monday's Age which makes reference to the intervention by senior Customs officers in normal Customs procedures resulting in the suspension of the normal practice of Customs inspections. How prevalent is this practice whereby simply on the basis of a Minister's nod Ministers are ushered through without any check whatsoever? Can the Minister give an estimate of how much revenue was lost in the last two years as a result of this practice?

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —On all of the occasions that are relevant in this case and in others the Government has made it quite clear that Ministers of the Crown and members of parliament generally should be treated in no way different from ordinary members of the public. In fact in a telex dated 23 February 1976 Mr Carmody, the then Secretary of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, stated:

answer.para: The Government has decided that all Australians on their return from overseas journey receive equal treatment in respect of the enforcement of the Customs and quarantine regulations.
He goes on to say:

I have been instructed that all Federal and State parliamentarians (including Ministers of State), government officials, and notable Australian dignitaries of every description undergo the same Customs and quarantine formalities as other Australian citizens.

As to the veracity of the article referred to by Senator Foreman-I believe he quoted from the Age-I do not have that article in front of me and there is no way in which I can deal with that matter. I will draw it to the attention of the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Brown, and obtain a detailed reply about that episode. The honourable senator also raised the question of revenue that may or may not have been lost in this situation. I believe that that takes into account factors that are not available to us at present in any description. Clearly, by virtue of the telex which I have just read out to the Senate, it is not the kind of question that can be answered in any way at all. We understand that Customs officials have undertaken their duties properly and have ensured that all returning members of parliament and Ministers have been treated equally.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed in part to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services and in part to the Attorney-General. In view of the advertisements on the local radio station 2XX for people to join with the Ex-servicemen for Peace and Disarmament and the Canberra College of Advanced Education students, will the Minister tell the Senate what inquiries were carried out by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to establish the bona fides of these groups before granting them permission to join the Anzac Day march? Will the Minister give consideration to meeting the costs of the Council of the Australian War Memorial and the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Returned Services League in any challenge they wish to mount in the Supreme Court to establish the bona fides of these organisations to join the traditional Anzac march? Will the Minister give consideration to banning all visual media coverage of the event?

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —The question asked by Senator Reid falls into three parts. I think each part really falls within the province of a separate Minister. In the third part of the question the honourable senator seeks consideration to be given to banning visual media coverage. That clearly is within the responsibility of the Minister for Communications to whom I will refer the request. I cannot give an answer on behalf of Mr Newman, the Minister for Administrative Services.

answer.para: The second part of the question relates to giving consideration to meeting the costs of the Council of the Australian War Memorial and the Australian Capital Territory branch of the RSL in any challenge that they might wish to raise. That is properly a matter for the Attorney-General who may or may not wish to add some comment to what I am about to say.

In relation to the first part of the question, I can only inform the honourable senator that the inquiries that were made were based upon the terms of the application of the group. The Australian Federal Police took the application and made inquiries based upon what was written in the application. I am advised that the details of the methods of investigation by law enforcement bodies are matters which have regard to privacy and confidentiality. Because of this I have not been supplied with the detailed way in which the applications were investigated.

talk.start.para: —I just add some information on the part of the question which concerned me. I was advised last week that the RSL-I had not heard of the Australian War Memorial in this regard-was giving consideration to challenging in the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory the decision of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police concerning the rights of three organisations to take part in the Anzac Day march. I had commenced to give that matter consideration. Before any final decisions were made I was informed the the RSL has decided not to make any challenge. The question really does not arise now.

question.block.title: LAND TENURE OF QUEENSLAND ABORIGINES AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDERS

talk.start.para: —Does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs acknowledge that the analysis by the barrister Frank Brennan and Bill Pincus, Q.C., of the Queensland Government's legislation providing deed of grant in trust arrangements for the Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander reserves concludes that this legislation offers no security of tenure to Aboriginal owners? In the light of the Minister's frequent and public repetition that he would insist on four criteria being met in this matter, including perhaps especially, the criterion of security of tenure, why has he accepted the Queensland legislation? Why has he reneged on his undertaking to Queensland Aboriginals and Islanders that security of tenure would be achieved?

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —I have read the analysis by the Reverend Mr Brennan. I have read one which was not attributed to anyone but which I take it is the one by Mr Pincus, Q.C., which was produced at about the same time. I believe the conclusions that they drew are as set out by Senator Ryan. Honourable senators may wish to consider the position which Aboriginal reserve communities in Queensland faced 15 months ago when the question was first raised that the Acts might be abolished and the reserves might be abolished. At that stage the Aboriginal communities faced the prospect of being left completely in a legal limbo living on crown land. The announcement by the Queensland Government on 1 March was an important one for Queensland Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders as it represented the greatest indication by the Queensland Government of a desire to accommodate the communities with land tenure and with title.

answer.para: The Queensland Government's proposals and the subsequent legislation which has been passed represent a significant advance for reserve communities in Queensland. They are capable of meeting some of the principles which I outlined in the Senate on 19 August 1981. I say 'some of the principles' because Queensland has yet to develop its proposals on self-management and on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Acts. Honourable senators will know that the amendments so far are to the lands Acts which are concerned with tenure. The proposals which have now passes through the Queensland Parliament will mean that communities will have a title to their reserves, which they did not have previously. It will be perpetual title which will be held directly by the communities and not by a white intermediary. The title can be removed only by the Parliament of Queensland. There will be parliamentary review of any act of revocation although I think that will be a very unlikely act. It is a major advance to put title and responsibility for land in Queensland reserves into the hands of the community councils rather than having a single government official as a trustee of the reserve.

In its announcement of 1 March, the Queensland Government indicated its intention to make this legislation work. The Commonwealth believes that the Queensland Government has acted in good faith in the changes it has made to the lands Acts. The Commonwealth still has some reservations, particularly about the possibile resumption of land which might occur during a parliamentary recess or before the Parliament had a chance to exercise its judgment. It is because of those concerns that the Commonwealth has backed up Queensland's action with its own unequivocal guarantee. I remind honourable senators that the Commonwealth has given an unequivocal guarantee that it will stand behind the stated intent of the Queensland Government to provide security of tenure and integrity to the reserve land. It has given an unequivocal guarantee that if actions transgressed these principles or indicated an unreasonable use of the discretions available under the legislation, the Commonwealth would act accordingly.

I put it to the Senate that one has to consider the amendments which have been made, the amendments which have yet to be produced and our guarantee, if one is to look at the package as a whole. It is one thing to look at the worst possible scenario one could draw on a legal analysis of document; it is another to look at that law and combine it with the Commonwealth's guarantee and some appreciation of the political realities applying in Australia in 1982.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. I refer to the Minister's statement that the Commonwealth has given an unequivocal guarantee for security of tenure. Does that mean that, if the Queensland Government withdrew the grant in trust title from an Aboriginal community, the Commonwealth Government would, in pursuit of this security of tenure, acquire that land so that security of tenure could be granted at the Commonwealth level? If it does not mean that, what does it mean?

—Because there might be a variety of ways in which the Commonwealth might have to respond to meet a variety of situations, I say simply that the guarantee means what it says. We will test it as the occasion arises.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Has the degree of Australian self-sufficiency in oil changed markedly in recent years? If so, what is the reason? Is the present figure for self-sufficiency 65 per cent? If so, what are the prospects of preventing this figure falling below that point? How important is it to do so in terms of energy cost to the nation and the individual consumer?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —The figures have been given to the Senate by me on a number of occasions. Several years ago when I first took over this portfolio, Australia's self-sufficiency in oil was 67 per cent. Therefore there was a need for a 33 per cent oil importation. It was also pointed out that, unless there were further discoveries, there would be a decline to 50 per cent by 1985, 40 per cent by 1990 and even to 10 per cent by the end of the century. That would have been very serious indeed and so a series of stimuli were applied to produce alternatives by way of exploration, conservation and conversion. At this point self-sufficiency remains at 67 per cent, although in the last few months industrial strife in Bass Strait has lowered the output of indigenous crude to about 65 per cent. The known reserves are now greater than they were some two, three of four years ago. That is a healthy situation.

answer.para: One cannot be over-optimistic about the projections but there has been record exploration. One in every four of the wildcat wells has produced a showing of oil which is very encouraging. Certainly there will not be a drop in self- sufficiency of the kind that we felt two or three years ago. It is even thought that with any reasonable optimism we may continue at about the 60 per cent level until at least the latter part of this decade and even to the end of it. But this figure will need to be revised as each year goes by.

talk.start.para: —I ask the Attorney-General whether either Mr Moore or Mr MacKellar approached him at any time between 5 October and 19 April, last night, for legal advice of any kind arising out of the events surrounding Mr MacKellar' s arrival in Australia on 5 October last year?
—No.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I believe the Minister concerned is Senator Messner. It is normally Senator Chaney.
—They chop and change so much, it is hard to keep up with them.

—Senator Chaney is overseas and Senator Messner is standing in for him at the moment. Is it a fact that Tasmania, which exports a large percentage of the total Australian exports of apples, has only one export licence whereas Western Australia has nine, New South Wales has 12, Victoria has 12 and so on? Is it a fact that most Tasmanian growers want more than one licensed exporter and in this they are supported by the Australian Apple and Pear Growers Association? Is it a fact that the Apple and Pear Corporation rejected an application for a second licence, notwithstanding that all the grower members of the Board voted for it? Is it a fact that a renewed application has been made dated 13 April 1982? Will the Minister instruct the Government representative on the Board to seek to have this application dealt with urgently for the current season and that it be supported by that representative? Further, will any other step lead to an inevitable glut on the Australian domestic market caused by many Tasmanian growers selling in that market rather than risking further huge losses by exporting through the failed Tasmanian Apple and Pear Marketing Authority?

—I hope that Senator Rae will appreciate that it is only since this morning that I have responsibility for this matter. I do not have all the facts connected with it at my fingertips. However, I will undertake to refer the very detailed question to the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, and ask for his urgent reply.
—It is urgent.
—I can see that.

debate.sub1.title: Third Report of the Sixtieth Session

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —I present the third report for the 60th session of the Standing Orders Committee.

interject.para: Ordered that the report be printed.
Motion (by Senator Sir John Carrick) agreed to:
That consideration of the report in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

speech.speaker: Georges Sen G.

talk.start.para: — On behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts I present the 193rd, 194th and 195th reports of the Committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the reports be printed.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I have a tabling statement of some seven pages but because of time restraints on the Senate I will merely refer to certain sections of that statement and then seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard. The 193rd report deals with certain administrative aspects of the Departments of Defence, Transport, Foreign Affairs and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority and also comments upon the accounting procedures at overseas posts. In relation to the Department of Transport, we found no fault with the administration of the second harbour bridge construction in Tasmania, nor did the Committee have any criticism of administration at the HMAS Stirling naval base in Western Australia.

speech.para: The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority was examined in respect of its delays in presenting adequately framed financial statements for auditing purposes from 1976 to 1979. We have made significant criticisms of that Authority's accounting practices. In the case of accounting for non-governmental moneys we have recommended immediate amendments to the Australian Capital Schools Authority Ordinance. The 194th report contains matters arising from the Advance to the Minister for Finance. We examined the administrative expenses of the Australian Federal Police and the natural disaster relief and restoration funding administered by the Department of Finance.

The 195th report of this Committee deals with responses to the Committee's earlier inquiry into the financing and administration of property owned or leased overseas. Delays in responding to the Committee's earlier reports have been judged to be unacceptable. Before I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement, I point out that I think it is necessary for all honourable senators to refer to certain chapters in this report because in making such a brief statement I have not outlined some of the main criticisms and recommendations of the Committee. I believe it is necessary for the honourable senators to view the incorporated statement in Hansard. I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
TABLING SPEECH
193rd Report

The 193rd report refers to our investigation into certain aspects of the administration of the Departments of Defence, Transport, Foreign Affairs and the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. Our inquiry arose out of unfavourable comment by the Auditor-General in his reports for 1979-80 and March 1981. In relation to the Department of Defence the Committee concerned itself with the administration of HMAS Stirling, the naval base in Western Australia. We were generally satisfied with our findings. Likewise, in relation to the second harbour bridge construction, we looked at the Department of Transport's administrative activities and are satisfied that this agency acted properly in its use of the Commonwealth's financial commitment in this area.

Our examination of delays by the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority in presenting adequately framed financial statements for auditing purposes in respect of the years from 1976 to 1979 resulted in a number of important conclusions. We also comment upon the adequacy of that Authority's procedures for accounting for receipt and use of non-government moneys. The Committee finds the delay in presentation of financial reports quite unacceptable. We consider that the financial reports of the Authority should be presented to the Minister within three months of the close of the financial year. Similarly, we are disturbed that the Authority continues to use a cash based accounting system in spite of continued requests by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance to adopt accrual accounting. Our firm recommendation is that this be resolved urgently.

Regarding accounting for non-government moneys, the Committee recommends appropriate amendments to the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority Ordinance 1976 be drafted without delay to rectify this accounting anomaly.

With respect to the Department of Foreign Affairs we examined comments in the Auditor-General's report for March 1981 relating to accounting at overseas posts . We make recommendations in this area which will have bearing upon cases such as that of embezzled money from the Australian Embassy in Washington, which was reported in January of this year. The Committee is considering this particular case, I should add, and will advise on its findings at a later date.
194th Report

This report deals with the Committee's examination of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, 1980-81. Expenditure by departments from the advance during that year was approximately $47.4m. In its annual inquiry into the advance, the Committee seeks to determine whether or not expenditure charged to the advance could have reasonably been foreseen in time for its inclusion in the additional estimates. As part of this approach, the Committee examines departments on the efficiency of their administration.

The Committee requires departments to submit explanations in respect of all items of expenditure from the advance. In 1980-81 it received 129 explanations in relation to these items, and requested supplementary written information for 31 of the items from 12 departments. As part of the inquiry the Committee examined in public hearings the Australian Federal Police in relation to its administrative expenses, the medical and dental services of the Department of Defence, the Department of Finance on natural disaster relief and restoration funding, and the Department of Industry and Commerce on reserve capacity maintenance.

The Committee's examinations revealed that in all cases expenditure from the advance was properly confined, that is, it met urgent and unforeseen requirements. However, we were concerned that some departments provided insufficient information in their initial submissions forcing us to make supplementary requests and causing undue delay. The Committee expects to see a considerable improvement in the 1981-82 submissions.

This report also makes recommendations designed to improve the effectiveness of the programs which were examined. For example, the Committee's recommendations concerning the utilisation of defence hospitals by dependants of servicemen, and the need for the development of more suitable undergraduate training schemes, should improve the recruitment of service medical personnel.

Implementation of the recommendations concerning the administration of natural disaster relief and restoration funding involve the Commonwealth adopting a more active role in approving relief measures. This should reduce the time taken for payments to be made.

The Committee's examination of reserve capacity maintenance at government factories indicated that the major issues were the length of time taken to resolve compensation cases and the incidence of appeal by the Commonwealth in such cases. The Committee will be considering this matter further in consultation with its legal advisors.
195th Report

The 195th report details follow-up action taken on the Committee's recommendations and conclusions from our investigations of the financing and administration of property owned or leased overseas by the Commonwealth Government. The inquiry was prompted by the reorganisation of the Overseas Property Bureau, which was abolished in 1976 and its functions absorbed by the Department of Administrative Services. The Committee then broadened its inquiry to include organisations representing officers and their families serving overseas. The findings of the inquiry were tabled in 1978 as report 172.

The response to the Committee, in the form of a Department of Finance minute prepared by an interdepartmental committee, was received in June 1980. After considering the finance minute the Committee decided that the response to certain recommendations was inadequate. Further information was sought at subsequent meetings in August and October 1981.

The excessive time taken to resolve this finance minute is not acceptable to my Committee. Two years elapsed from tabling of the report until receipt of a response. Then certain aspects of the response required further follow up. The original response to many sections of the report was generally obtuse and did not pay due regard to our requirements.

The Committee believes timely, accurate and complete feedback is essential if the full effects of its reports are to be realised. The conclusions and recommendations of the 172nd report were designed to draw attention to instances of administrative inefficiency and procedural weakness and consequently to improve the quality of public administration.

In relation to the finance minute on this report several matters are outstanding. The effect upon recovery for losses sustained through property damages and cleaning expenses of a joint management review of overseas accounting recommendations. The results of a review of the setting of rent ceilings. The Committee expects to be advised on the outstanding matters contained in this report at six-monthly intervals from this tabling until resolution.
In speaking on these reports I wish also to draw the Parliament's attention to delays we have experienced in receiving finance minutes on numerous of our reports.

The Department of Finance co-ordinates departmental responses to my Committee's reports, and sends us regular reports indicating progress in each department. They are dependent upon the co-operation of these departments in compiling the necessary responses which comprise a finance minute.
Clearly, the Department of Finance is beyond reproach in its supervisory function. But its job has of late been made difficult by delays from various departments.

The response by the Department of Health to our 182nd report, on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, tabled in September 1980, is one example of unacceptable delay which continues to occur. The response to our discussion paper on internal audit has also been slow, as has been the case with other matters contained within the 186th report on the advance to the Minister for Finance. In the case of our report on the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, the progress of Attorney-General's in responding to a major recommendation was glacial. This particular matter became so serious, and the delay so damaging, that I will be making a separate statement about it.
The Committee wishes to put on record that it finds such delays quite unacceptable and that it expects, and will demand, better compliance from agencies in future.
