debate.title: CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 18 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1982 extends to steaming coal and some other types of coal an export levy at the rate of $1 per tonne. Ever since 1975 there has been a levy on higher grade coking coal which currently rests at $3.50 per tonne and it will remain at that level for the indefinite future, I presume, in spite of Government guarantees given about three years ago that the levy would be abolished. This move and the earlier application of a $3.50 per tonne levy on higher quality coking coal seeks to capture the economic rent component of coal prices. It is appropriate, in the view of the Australian Labor Party, that economic rent should be captured by governments for the benefit of the entire community. For that reason the Labor Party does not oppose this Bill. However, this particular form of capturing economic rent through a quantum levy is crude and inefficient. It is a means of capturing rent retained only because of the original opportunism and subsequent intransigence, even stupidity, of the members of the present Government. Although we approve of the objective we do not approve of the method. On behalf of the Opposition I move:

speech.para: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the existing coal export levies are indiscriminate and calls upon the Government to introduce legislation to abolish the coal export duty and replace it with a resource rent tax which takes into account the real level of costs and profits.'.

The concept of economic rent is not easy to grasp and, even when it is grasped, the magnitude of the economic rent component of any price is not easy to define precisely. Economic rent in its simplest and original form, as defined by Ricardo about 150 years ago, is the difference between the yield of grain from the least productive land in cultivation and the higher yield from all other land. That definition, of course, was given in a predominantly agricultural and simple economy. In today's more complex economy it could probably be best defined as any return to capital or labour in excess of that required to attract and hold the necessary amounts of capital and labour in an industry.

Economic rent conceptually takes many forms. It accrues to high grade and/or very accessible ore bodies. It accrues to fertile land. It accrues also to any holder of a monopoly right to participate in industry granted by a government or , perhaps more precisely, any monopoly right which carries with it monopoly power, such as quotas to keep hens, quotas to supply milk to protected markets, television licences and probably airline licences. Obviously, given the definition of economic rent as any return in excess of that required to attract and hold the necessary amounts of capital and labour in an industry, it follows that any sudden, unexpected windfall price gain will generate economic rent for people who were previously producing commodities for which the price gain occurred, particularly if the means of producing those commodities are not reproducible. That is what happened to existing oil producers after the oil price hike of 1973 because of the indirect effect of that oil price hike, windfall gains and economic rent spilt over into coal as, to some degree at least, an alternative to oil.

Anyone who has a nodding acquaintance with the subject should be aware of that. As I said earlier, it is difficult if not impossible, even for those who have grasped the concept, to isolate with precision the economic rent component from the total price. If that could be done with precision-I acknowledge that it cannot-it would be possible to tax away 100 per cent of that economic rent component, to appropriate it for the community, whereas any quantum levy will interfere with efficiency. The reason that any quantum levy will interfere with efficiency is that it violates the basic rule of efficient taxation; namely, that there should be no tax on marginal production-that is, production the cost of which is exactly equal to its market price. A resource rent tax-a tax related to profits instead of to production-that is accurately assessed imposes no tax at the margin. Any quantum levy-I stress any quantum levy-imposes a tax at the margin and therefore intereferes with efficiency.

The economic principles which I have attempted to summarise ought to be understood, although they probably are not, by certainly any economics graduate and probably by anyone who has successfully completed the first year course. It is lamentable to report that they are apparently not understood by at least some , if not all, of the Ministers of this Government and by the Acting Director of the Australian Mining Industry Council, Mr Game. All of these people have failed to grasp the simple fact that at any level of taxation, at any level of community appropriation of the economic rent component of price, a resource rent tax is a more efficient system of taxation than any quantum levy. All the members of the Mining Industry Council do not necessarily support the views that its Acting Director, Mr Game, puts in public, so I will refer just to Mr Game's views. It appears from Mr Game's public statement that he has failed to realise that, with a variety of overt and covert quantum levies, State and Federal Governments are already appropriating the greater part of the economic rent in those projects to which it most spectacularly accrues, being Bass Strait oil and Bowen Basin coal.

There is a separate argument-a political argument, perhaps-derived from value judgments about whether the state should appropriate or attempt to appropriate 100 per cent of the economic rent component or whether it should settle for something less than that. That is one argument. My view is that if it were technically feasible-it is not quite because there are some variables that cannot be precisely identified in advance-all of the economic rent should be appropriated by the community. I hasten to add that that would have no effect on the efficiency of resource allocation. The second question, having determined the separate issue of what is the appropriate level of taxation, of appropriation of economic rent, concerns the means by which that revenue is collected or harvested. For the reasons that I have stated previously, it is inarguable that at any level of taxation, of appropriation of rent, it is more efficient to do it with a resource rent tax than with a quantum levy. It is deplorable that that logically inescapable conclusion, which ought to be understood by anyone who has done a fairly elementary economics course, apparently escapes the comprehension of Ministers of this Government.

It might help if, using figures which approximate the figures which actually apply now, I give a practical example of the way in which quantum levies impede efficiency and profit related taxes do not. Bass Strait oil is priced to Australian oil refiners at $30 a barrel. Of that $30, on average, the producers receive about $7. The actual cost of production is probably less than $2 a barrel. The producers receive about $7. The price paid by the refiners is $30. The $23 difference between the price received by the producer and the price paid by the refiners is absorbed by quantum levies imposed by the Government of Victoria and the Commonwealth Government. At some time as those fields approach exhaustion the cost of extracting that oil-I am using average figures to simplify the proposition-will exceed the price received by the producers. In other words, the producers are now receiving $7 and they are paying $23 excise.

When the cost of actually extracting the oil reaches $10 a barrel, other things being equal, the total cost to the producers of production plus tax will be $33- $10 production cost plus $23 tax. With a market price at $30 it follows quite clearly that those fields will stop producing unless something is changed. Of course, in those circumstances I think not even the present Government could be so crass as to fail to change something. I do not believe that even the present Government would be so crass that it would allow fields which produce oil at $10 a barrel, which has a market value of $30 a barrel, to be abandoned. So much for the quantum levy. That is why it is not very efficient at capturing economic rent for the community and it interferes with the efficient allocation of resources and efficient management decisions.

A profits related tax, on the other hand-still with the same basic assumptions- would ensure that oil continued to be produced from those fields until the cost of actually extracting it was equal to its market price; in other words, until the cost of actually extracting it was $30, the same as the assumed market price . Under the present Government system production would cease when the cost of extraction exceeded $7. That relates to the point I made earlier, that with a resources rent tax no tax is imposed on marginal production. A properly designed resources rent tax-this figure will vary somewhat depending on what the product is and how many uncertain variables there may be-will capture probably around 90 per cent of the total economic rent for the community without impeding efficiency or interfering with sound management decisions.

The principles I have explained are, of course, most relevant and most important when they are applied to those mineral deposits which have a very high economic rent component, where a high proportion of the market price is economic rent. Nothing is as high in Australia right now as Bass Strait oil. Probably more than 80 per cent of the market price is economic rent. For even the best of Bowen Basin coal it is considerably less than that. When we get down to considering iron ore mines and most of the gold mines in Australia we see that the economic rent component is even less, although in the case of gold it is highly variable because of the vast range in the grade of ore which is mined and also-sometimes compounding with each other-the accessibility of it.

In conclusion, on behalf of the Opposition I have moved the amendment to the motion for the second reading. We support the basic objective that the Government is pursuing with this Bill. We deplore the fact that the Government has chosen to do it in such an inefficient way. It is an error-I suppose one could charitably call it an error-which we seek to ameliorate to some extent by this amendment to the motion for the second reading.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: —This afternoon we are debating at the second reading stage the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1982. The present coal export duty applies to export of coking coal at the rates of either $3.50 per tonne or $1 per tonne depending on the quality of the coal and certain other features of the mining operation. At the moment there is no duty on steaming coal. The present rates are below those which applied when the Government came to office. But it is considered Government policy that it is no longer thought appropriate to phase out the duty, which was the original intention some years ago. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill states:

speech.para: The purpose of the Bill is to enact the Customs Tariff alterations introduced into the Parliament on 18 August 1981 by the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Proposal (1981) which formally proposed, with effect from 8 p.m. on 18 August 1981, an export duty of $1 per tonne on black coal previously exempt from export duty.

The coal industry faces a variety of charges imposed by the Commonwealth Government and by the various State governments. Unfortunately there is very little co-ordination in the implementation and imposition of the charges. For example, the Commonwealth Government collects normal corporate tax on company profits at the rate of 46 per cent and coal export duty at the rate of $1 or $3. 50 per tonne depending on the quality and depth of extraction. Also there is a component in relation to long service leave. Today we introduced a Bill to lift the limit from 15c to 25c to cover long service leave amendments. Then there are a variety of State government taxes and charges. For example, I will refer specifically to some of these charges imposed by New South Wales. In the case of coal there is a levy in the form of a royalty which is a charge by the State Government for the right to extract the coal. That is fairly normal. In addition to that royalty there is a super-royalty which is an additional amount based on what is called a minor project basis. Little or virtually no royalty is paid on marginal coal leases, whereas royalties on profitable leases can be quite high. There is a large element of discrimination.

There is also a rail freight charge. The New South Wales Government, in common with practices adopted by the Queensland Government, extracts a form of levy, royalty or excise-whatever one likes to call it. It is an additional amount in the form of a rail freight charge. A supercharge is incorporated in that charge. In other words, there is a taxation component within the rail freight element charged certainly by the governments of New South Wales and Queensland. In addition, there is a ship loading charge and wharfage fees, which are quite high , and a harbour deepening charge. I think we are all aware of many of the problems the industry is facing, particularly in New South Wales. If one looks at the overall situation, one sees that in 1980-81 coal exports comprised 10 per cent of the total export income of Australia. We are now facing depression in economic activity and, unfortunately, I believe we are not helping ourselves a great deal in some areas. For example, I was told today that a vessel that entered the port of Newcastle to load coal had been waiting off the coast for 75 days. I suppose where there is an excess supply of shipping in relation to world demands ship owners possibly are prepared to leave ships off the coast for an average of between 30 and 39 days. That is intolerable. As world economic activity picks up, no ship owner will allow his ship to stay off the coast of New South Wales at an average cost of $10,000 a day for such periods.

There is a strong argument for an additional loading facility to be provided, not necessarily in the port of Newcastle with its high levels of congestion but somewhere else-say, Botany. I know there are some environmental problems there. Maybe the opportunity should be given to private enterprise to develop a facility like the one at Hay Point somewhere else down the coast. It would be necessary, of course, to have that loading facility connected to the main rail system. The problem is accentuated by high Commonwealth charges in some cases and exorbitant charges by State governments which are virtually reaping a levy in their own right. We may well say that this is not necessarily the best form of taxation, but if the Commonwealth moved out of this field what would happen? The States would immediately move in to take up the difference, and I think rightly so. From the Commonwealth's point of view there should be some adequate return to it. After all, we have to regard this not only as a State resource but also as a Commonwealth resource.

There are problems with the coal industry at the moment. There are high levels of industrial activity, particularly in New South Wales. This high level of industrial activity is causing a degree of instability, sharp increases in costs , many of which have been brought about by government action, congestion in the ports and so on. One wonders whether in the long term the future exports of coal will essentially come from the State of Queensland rather than from the State of New South Wales. I think the employment consequences could be quite horrific unless all concerned combine to put their houses in order in New South Wales. The Japanese, Koreans and the Taiwanese will not indefinitely put up with unreliability of supply and higher than necessary cost structures. I can foresee a gradual movement towards the opening up of more mines in Queensland and the development of additional port facilities in Queensland unless the New South Wales Government and the colliery owners, the workers and the unions-the whole lot-put their acts together and try to develop an economic and viable export coal industry in that State.

On top of that we now face an oil glut. Prices are falling. One may well ask: Will there be a tendency to move towards coal, particularly amongst the high energy, heavy industry countries such as Japan, Taiwan and Korea? The indications are that in Japan there is a move away from high energy utilisation industries to the application of manpower in high technology industries. Therefore, the growth in coal exports to Japan will not necessarily be at such an accelerated rate as in the past. I think development in this area lies very closely with Korea and Taiwan. But there is the general problem facing the industry throughout Australia, but particularly in New South Wales, of costs rising far faster than selling prices. It is true that lately there have been some increases in the selling prices of steaming coal, which proves that it is in demand, but Australia has to be able to prove that it is a reliable supplier. If we look to the longer term we must consider the impact that nuclear energy will have on the coal industry. Whilst Australia has fairly low reserves of coal -about 4 per cent of the world's reserves-its command of the trade is approximately 20 per cent, which is quite high. Looking into the longer term, if nuclear energy is utilised, there could be doubts about the long term future of the coal industry. We have to recognise that environmental difficulties are associated not only with the mining but also with the transport and storage of coal. With increased technology available in the nuclear industry, in the next 10 to 15 years we may well find that nuclear energy will replace coal energy.

I believe there needs to be some consistency between the State and Federal governments in the application of the various charges and levies that relate to the coal industry. The imposition on some companies of the various charges is quite severe. For example, in 1981 the annual review of the Utah Development Co. stated its total income. The various governments' share was 72 per cent, leaving 28 per cent to the company. The review did not define the term 'income', but I think the figures, despite the lack of definition, are sufficiently high to cause some worry and concern. There is also a concern within the Utah company that certain discrimination is exercised against it. In terms of world trading conditions I do not think this is an appropriate form of taxation. A company which happens to secure a reasonable lease and uses modern techniques of extraction can suddenly find itself with charges which are far higher than those which pertain to the rest of the industry. There is also a great deal of uncertainty when one considers the whole ramifications of the coal export duty, because there are certain problems. I understand that one company at present has some disputation with the Customs section relating to certain technical features and to differences in technology between open cut and underground mining. In the international scene, potential investors must regard the position in Australia as a matter of some concern.

I mentioned that the development of world markets for energy and resources and the consequent strengthening of export demands for steaming coal indicate that there is no great reason for differentiating between coking and steaming coal in the application of duty. However, I think we must also consider the problems that I raised earlier. I mentioned that the purpose of the Bill is to impose an export duty of $1 per tonne on black coal, which was previously exempt. Steaming coal, of course, is in demand because of the increases in the price of oil that occurred in 1979. While there is some temporary softening in the price of oil, it is difficult to see how long these lower prices will prevail. A lot depends on the political condition of many of those countries in the Middle East. It would be surprising if softening of prices extended very much more than six months.

In the long term, we see that action is being taken by Saudi Arabia to reduce its flow of oil on to world markets. Despite the unreliability of some of the figures coming from some of those countries, there will be a determination to try to reduce the flow, to some extent, to keep the prices up. So in the long term there will be the continued tendency to move away from oil and move back towards coal as an energy source. I mentioned earlier-and I must emphasise this- that there is no point in having a coal export levy or trying to produce and to develop an industry if we are in a situation where these enormous delays in shipping virtually cut the very heart out of profitability and industry. There must be a way to overcome this dilemma in terms of congestion and industrial disputation. I stress that the cause of the industrial disputation needs a more thorough evaluation and analysis. I do not believe that the problems necessarily are caused by the unionists. The techniques employed and the lack of communication between management and men have all to be considered. There needs to be a greater effort by both the Commonwealth Government, which has a vested interest in this matter, and the State governments, to try to put their house in order or the full potential of this industry will not be realised.

We have to recognise also that coal is going through a new phase of development . Currently we are exporting something like 39 million tonnes of coking coal a year and over 9 million tonnes of steaming coal. The industry will continue to expand, I believe, particularly in the area of steaming coals. This buoyancy is reflected in recent price increases that have currently come towards the steaming sector of the market.

I mentioned that our reserves are considerable. While our reserves are considerable, we control about 18 to 20 per cent of world trade in export coal. It is a valuable industry which I believe the Federal Government and State governments have a vested interest in trying to protect. While the other sectors of the mineral industry are suffering depressed prices-one only has to look at the areas of tin and copper-there is some potential for growth in prices for export coal. I repeat: We have a vested interest in seeing that this valuable industry develops.

As honourable senators know, I have a vested interest in seeing that we have a high level of Australian ownership of these resources. I, therefore, quote from a study by Dr Folie of the Shell Co. of Australia Ltd. He estimated that the present level of foreign ownership of steaming coal was about 38 per cent. He predicted that this will rise to 50 per cent in the next ten years. Are Australian shareholders really reaping the full value of this export potential? In the case of coking coal, Dr Folie estimates that foreign ownership is already as high as 60 per cent. Because of the high levels of foreign ownership, many companies within the industry find that their profits are being repatriated abroad or just built up for further development in other industries in Australia . There appears to be a need for a tax, such as the export levy, whereby a further contribution other than the primary tax which is charged at the rate of 46 per cent is added to the component.

One also needs to examine some of the guidelines with investments. Some of the local companies, such as the Colonial Sugar Refining Co. Ltd and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, in addition to some of the life insurance companies, are moving into this market. Their big problem is that the level of savings to provide capital is not sufficiently high.

I believe a greater incentive should be given to ordinary Australians to invest in our resource industries. This could be done by a number of measures, such as by exempting from taxation dividends of under, say, $400 or $500 earned from such investments. Such action would encourage smaller investors to invest in the market. Alternatively, we should be devising our taxation system to give a greater incentive, particularly to the local type companies, to invest. I believe that a lot of the depreciation allowances do not recognise the fact that this industry has to operate in a world environment. This criticism applies not only to the coal industry but also to the whole of the mineral industry.

In our taxation system we must develop not only incentives but also a recognition of revenue sources and make allowance for the fact that the proportion of taxation income does not necessarily have a relationship to the manufacturing industries that operate in a State. The taxation system should recognise the fact that these industries have to compete on the world market. There is a need for greater flexibility in depreciation rates. At the same time we have to recognise that a lot of the costs that are incurred by mining companies are not allowable as taxation deductions. There is, therefore, a tendency to call upon local government to supply some of the charges and services that should rightly be borne by the mining companies themselves. If we had a more appropriate or indeed more equitable taxation system which, for example, recognised the right of a company to deduct the costs of building a bridge along a highway as a taxation expense, there would be much more incentive for the companies to undergo these sorts of expenditures rather than relying on State or local government to provide these services.

There is a need for a complete review of the taxation system to provide greater consistency in relation to the collection of revenue from the coal industry. We must look at the whole taxation system so far as the recognition of revenue and the appropriate deductibility of expenditure are concerned. I support the tenor of the Bill. I wish it a speedy passage through the Senate.

speech.speaker: Tate Sen M.C.

talk.start.para: —One of the premier articles in today's Australian Financial Review is headed 'Coal boom buried by a cost-price squeeze'. The first sentence of the article reads:

speech.para: The much discussed coal boom was finally buried at the third Australian Coal Conference on the Queensland Gold Coast yesterday.

I believe that the title and the whole tenor of that article and, indeed, the pronouncements on the health of the coal industry by Mr Bob White, the Chief General Manager of the Bank of New South Wales, and Mr Ray Craig, the Investment Manager of the AMP Society, are too gloomy by far. In fact, they do not take any account whatsoever-nor does the title of the article-of the fact that in the Senate chamber today we have one of the reasons why those involved in making investment decisions in the coal industry are feeling apprehensive. If there is anything that investment decision-makers require it is stability of the taxation environment in which they make those decisions. For example, on 18 August last year the Treasurer (Mr Howard) walked into the House of Representatives and announced out of the blue, without consultation with the industry, that a dollar levy would be placed on the export of lower-valued coals, principally steaming coals, formerly exempted from the coal export duty.

There is no doubt that the unpredictable and variable nature of the levies to which this industry is being subjected by the Federal and State governments is one of the reasons why there is some apprehension within the industry at the moment. It is most disturbing and, indeed, remarkable that the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) is not present while the Senate is debating the imposition of a levy on the export of coal from Australia, a levy which has been vehemently rejected by the Australian Coal Association, which represents virtually all the black coal producers throughout Australia and produces over 100 million tonnes of black coal. He does not even care to come into the chamber to defend the imposition of this levy. It seems remarkable that Senator Sir John Carrick should sit in his office while the Senate is debating the imposition of a tax on one of Australia's premier resource energy industries. But that is a measure of the contempt with which this Government has dealt with the coal export industry as a whole. I would have preferred the article in the Australian Financial Review to have paid heed to that fact rather than to talk only in terms of what it calls a cost-price squeeze and, as I say, speak in terms of doom and gloom, which seems to have been the pattern of that daily review of our financial affairs over the past fortnight or so.

The fact is, as honourable senators know, that the coal export industry stands on the verge of very substantial growth. In fact, it is a magnificent industry. The sorts of actions to which I have alluded and which we are debating of this Federal Government have created some problems with the investment decisions that need to be made. But there is no doubt that since and as a direct result of the decisions of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries this industry is now a thriving and generally profitable one. Previously the Australian economy definitely rode on the sheep's back. In 1978, for the first time, coal passed wool as Australia's major export earner. On a long term basis, although wheat exports may be higher in good crop years, coal looks like being Australia's number one export earner over the coming decade. In 1979-80, for example, exports of coal were worth $1,667m. That is about 10 per cent of the value of all our exports. With exports continuing to rise at an expected rate of about 7 per cent a year and more in money terms as prices rise with international inflation, I think we can expect this industry to contribute a considerable degree of wealth to the Australian economy.

Of course, we are unique amongst the world's black coal producers in that so much of our black coal is devoted to export. We mine about 100 million tonnes of coal a year. Half of it is for local use, particularly in our power generation and the making of steel. But the rest, which comes down to 45 million or 46 million tonnes after washing, is exported. This means that the industry is subject to international cycles in trade. Whilst steaming coal exports may be a little less volatile than coking coal exports, which are obviously related to the cyclical steel industry, nevertheless there is a judgment to be made by those who wish to invest in this industry as to the growth and future profitability of the international trade in which Australia is in a premier position. Largely, until now, we have devoted our coking coal exports to the Japanese steel furnaces. At the moment, we export per annum some 36 million tonnes of coking coal and seven million tonnes of steaming coal. That represents a dramatic increase in recent years, but is nothing like the tonnages of steaming coal that will be leaving this country during the next decade.

It all sounds very promising for Australia. It is therefore important to ensure that this great industry and the various projects based on this wonderful natural resource with which we are blessed are managed by both the private entrepreneurs concerned and by governments in such a way that the return to the Australian people is fair and helps to distribute wealth in a way which increases the well-being of all Australians, not just those immediately connected with the industry, whether they be shareholders or the workers within the industry who demand quite high wages for their work within it. When one looks at the distribution of moneys from the coal industry one sees that governments are doing very well. In fact, the real profit earners in the coal business can be said to be States and Federal governments. In 1979-80 government earned nearly four times as much as the coal companies-in dollar terms, of the order of $600m against a net operating profit for the export coal industry of around $150m. That is a very considerable contribution directly to government revenues.

I have seen a table which indicates the percentage allocation of coal export revenues. For example, for New South Wales the list is as follows: the State Government gets 15.6 per cent of coal export revenue; the Federal Government, 15 per cent; local government, 1.5 per cent; company profits, 3.6 per cent; employee after-tax pay, 26.3 per cent; State services, 14.6 per cent; Federal services, 1 per cent; other costs, 22.4 per cent. There is no doubt that when one looks at the wealth being distributed throughout the Australian economy as a result of the activities of the export coal industry one see that governments are doing very well. But the question is-this is the whole point of this amendment-whether the fiscal burdens imposed by Federal and State governments are, indeed fair and do create that predictable environment which, as I have said, is so necessary for the orderly and sensible decision-making of investors such as the Chief General Manager of the Bank of New South Wales and the Investment Manager of the AMP Society, two men who between them control by far the greatest investment power that could be marshalled in this country. This is a marshalling of the small contributions of many small policy holders in the AMP Society and those small savers with the Bank of New South Wales. They marshal these tremendous investment resources and they need to know that the fiscal burdens imposed by the Federal Government are indeed fair and predictable. I would say-I think any objective observer of the industry would say-that the coal export duty is not able to be characterised in that way. When one looks at that coal export duty one finds that its history is one of constant change culminating only in yet another announcement of an impost in the last Federal Budget.

Honourable senators will remember that the coal export duty was originally imposed in the 1975 Federal Budget. At that time the Liberal-National Country Party coalition opposed that tax on the grounds that it was discriminatory and that it would sap the industry of capital for new developments. My submission to the chamber is that in that regard the Opposition at that time was probably right but perhaps we did not recognise it as quickly as we ought to have done. The duty was originally $6 per tonne for hard and semi-hard coking coals and $2 per tonne for soft coking coals. This was lowered to $4.50 and $1.50 in the 1976 Budget and further lowered to $3.50 and $1 in 1977 as the deleterious impact of the levy imposed at those rates by the Federal Labor Government became apparent. That is an admission which we make quite freely. We have learnt from the experience and have a proposal to make which we believe will overcome the distorting effect of that system of gaining revenue for the Federal Treasury from this great export industry.

The 1977 rate remained at that level in the 1978 Budget with the promise then made by this Government that the duty would be abolished on 30 June 1979. However, in the mini-Budget of May 1979 the Treasurer, Mr Howard, announced that because of the stringency of the Budget situation and the essential requirements to bring down the deficit the Government had decided to retain the duty. So once again, despite an environment where both sides of politics recognised that the duty was inequitable, harsh, distorting investment decisions and having an unfair impact on various producers with quite different mining operations, this Government has persisted with the coal export duty. In the 1979 Budget the duty, which was retained at the previous levels except for hard and semi-hard coking coal won by underground methods, was reduced to $1 per tonne, the same as for soft coking coal.

In October 1979 the duty was varied once again. The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, announced that the duty on hard coking coal won by open-cut method with an overburden exceeding 60 metres would be reduced to $1 per tonne. In addition, exporters of coal with an ash content greater than 12 per cent or a swell index less than 3 per cent would not pay the duty. Because of its high ash content this latter coal must be sold as steaming coal despite its coking properties. In other words, again in October 1979 the Government recognised the variability of the types of coal and the mining operations required to win it. Obviously there is a difference in costs in removing an overburden of 70 metres as opposed to an overburden of 10 metres. This had not been recognised. It was partially recognised in this sliding scale of October 1979.

The then inevitably and, no doubt, without surprise to the industry on 18 August last year-on Budget night-the Treasurer announced that the Federal Government no longer considered it appropriate to phase out the duty. Because of developments in the world market for energy resources and the consequential strengthening of export demand for steaming coal, the Treasurer claimed that there was no longer any need to differentiate between coking and steaming coal. The $1 per tonne levy was therefore to be extended to cover all steam coal exports. It is that Bill with which we are dealing today.

From that short history this chamber would have been made aware or would have been reminded of something of which it no doubt was already aware, namely, that this provides a very fragile environment indeed for the decision makers in the coal industry to commit the vast sums of capital that are required. The reversal of government policy in this sort of manner from time to time and the constant variations, without any warning or without any proper consultations with the industry which would be required, have had the most severe effects on the confidence of investing authorities. They have to get some reasonable return on their investments in the future. They do not know the tax regime under which they will be acting or exporting.

Honourable senators would know that the lengthy period from five years to eight years to commence production in a mine requires constancy of policy over the period if confidence is to be maintained. I believe that it is this lack of confidence, not arising out of the international trading situation which is good for Australia, but arising out of the variation in the taxing policy of this Federal Government in relation to export coal, which has created the sort of apprehension which is legitimate but which, as I said at the beginning of my remarks, does not justify the sort of heading in the article in today's Australian Financial Review.

The Australian Labor Party is firmly opposed to this type of levy. We say-as we have said before-that it takes no account whatsoever of the differing mining conditions and hence the profitability of the industry. Our proposal is to so tax the industry that there is a true recognition of the varying profitability of projects or companies as they are looked at in their individuality. One has to look at the different infrastructure capital requirements, the geological situation and how these all work out in the profitability of a particular project. It is that profitability to which taxes ought to be related rather than some levy which depends on some crude amounts either being exported or mined at the pithead.

I believe that Senator Siddons for the Australian Democrats will be explaining in the course of his remarks the Democrats' proposal for a tax related to pithead production. But we say that even that, being related to crude quantities of coal being extracted from the earth, is just that-a crude method of levying a tax which bears no relationship to the profitability of the particular project. We say that it would be fairer for the coal industry concerned if indeed a tax varying with the profit were introduced. If that were the case then I believe that some of the investment projects for which feasibility studies have been done, which have been delayed because of the sorts of policy changes indulged in by this Government, could then go ahead.

Honourable senators will be well aware of the Labor Party's policy in relation to the resource rent tax. I have spoken on it at length in this chamber. Suffice to say that the Secretary to the Treasury finds nothing untoward when one is looking to return moneys to all Australians via some taxing mechanism which is fair, in the concept of a resource rent tax. Senate committees have found his remarks quite helpful in that respect.

As to the idea of a resource rent tax, I am surprised that it does not appeal to the Government on the simple basis, as I have said, that the coal industry finds the present coal export duty totally inequitable but, nevertheless, it must concede that, given the world energy situation, the higher profitability that might have been expected some years ago ought to enable it to contribute more to the Federal Treasury than normal company tax would return. If a resource rent tax were introduced by the Commonwealth I believe there would be several major gains to the Commonwealth in doing this. Firstly, there is little scope in raising ordinary income taxes as they are presently regarded as excessive by most Australians, whether one is talking about company tax or private individual income tax. So one cannot see any simple increase in those rates occurring. Secondly, the introduction of a resource rent tax is consistent with the Government's anti-inflation policy because the resource rent tax would not increase prices as indirect taxes would. The Commonwealth would easily be able to reduce the Budget deficit because of the larger potential of this particular tax. I think that this ought to be taken into account by the Government.

I believe it would be a rash government which continued, in the face of industry protest, with the coal export levy rather than try to come to some agreement with the industry on how its high profitability, when it occurs in relation to a particular project, can be tapped by the Federal Treasury. I am not saying that finding a formula will be easy but I believe that, as opposed to what has happened from time to time over the past four or five years, what ought to take place is the fullest possible consultation with the industry as to how that high profitability might be tapped, as I said, by the Federal Treasury. Consultation is the key. I think it is a very worthwhile thing indeed that a Senate standing committee is presently engaged in a review of the Australian export coal industry with a particular reference to its contribution to the economy. Whilst I am not a member of that standing committee I believe that the senators who are involved will come to much the same conclusions as I have indicated in my remarks today.

As I said, it is a cause for remark and somewhat disturbing that the Minister, who must have had much to say in the Cabinet room when the imposition of a further duty on steaming coal was proposed and who must have had more than his fair share of responsibility for the implementation of this proposal on Budget night of 1981, is not in the chamber this afternoon to defend this impost which has been rejected overwhelmingly by the industry, is rejected by the Australian Labor Party and, I believe, ought to be rejected by the Senate.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —The Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill gives effect to a Budget decision to place an export levy on certain types of coal previously exempt. It was estimated in the Budget Papers that the Bill would raise around $10m this financial year. It is planned that a total of $115m will come from coal export levies this year. The Australian Democrats support this Bill and wish it a speedy passage through the Senate. We are opposed to the amendment introduced by the Australian Labour Party, which in fact I saw only half an hour ago, for reasons which will become clear later during my remarks.

speech.para: Senator Tate outlined the great future the coal industry has in this country. We can only agree with him wholeheartedly. We believe that Australia's resource future generally is very great indeed and that levies, such as the one proposed in this Bill, offer a way of allowing ordinary Australians to reap some of the benefits of our vast and varied resources. Unless our resources are carefully planned and managed and their development proceeds at a rate that is compatible with capital generation in this country the benefits to most Australians from resource development will be very limited indeed.

Resources which are mined, such as coal, are essentially non-renewable-once they are used they are gone forever. The most important issue, therefore, surely is their conservation. The Democrats believe that this should be done through the application of a tax on tonnage mined-a pithead tax-such as this Bill employs. A pithead tax is justified, we believe, on the basis that the minerals and the energy resources in this country belong to all Australians. As a sovereign state, Australia has a right to use whatever resources may be found in this country for the common good to aid our defence, to pay for the development of infrastructure and, most importantly, to finance continued development. The primary objective, therefore, of a tax on tonnage mined is to conserve non- renewable resources and to encourage the establishment and exploitation of renewable resources. The Democrats approach to doing this differs very markedly from the approach of the Labor Party. It also, I might add, differs from the approach of the Government in that the Government's record so far has been very piecemeal and has lacked any long term planning.

We believe that applying a tax on raw materials used up-a pithead tax-and adjusting that tax to the level of the resources available, adjusting that tax to the local and world cost structures of the resources being sold, has a great advantage in that this sort of tax is trickeryproof in respect of companies exploiting transfer pricing. It could also take advantage of cost differentials in the mining of resources in various States. For instance, the costs of mining coal in Queensland by open cut methods are vastly different from the costs of deep mining in New South Wales. A pithead tax could take note of those variations in the costs of production and could be regulated accordingly. Anybody who thinks that much can be achieved by taxing profits is living, I am afraid, in a fool's paradise. If any honourable senator doubts this he or she should just carefully study the track record of the oil companies.

talk.start.para: —Are you equating profits with economic rent?

—I am referring to the track record of the oil companies. They have been very successful in avoiding tax by manipulating transfer pricing. Excess profits also become very dangerous because they essentially encourage inefficiency. We are strongly opposed to a tax on excess profits as being ineffectual, leading to inefficiency and imposing a burden on companies which is justified in no way in relation to the reserves that are being used up or to the future richness of the field.

speech.para: Where necessary, under our proposal of a pithead tax, the rates could be varied also to encourage the full exploitation of fields that are suffering from depletion and quantity differentials. I think Senator Tate said that such a tax would be extremely difficult to administer. I point out that the Government is currently applying such a tax in its levy on crude oil production. We say that this is the sort of tax that should be applied generally to all our mineral resources. The Government has demonstrated the feasibility of such an approach in its application of the crude oil levy. Of course, unfortunately, having successfully applied the levy on oil the Government is now proposing to phase it out since it has drawn a distinction between old and new oil.

The Government, although it has been on the right lines, is running one other grave risk as we see it. It is running the risk of wastage on a grand scale by not directing the moneys that it is raising from the levy towards specific and clearly set out national objectives. We are, in effect, squandering our national capital. I have said in this chamber many times-I will continue to say it-that we must effectively plan on a long term indicative basis if we are to manage effectively the economy of this country. Long term planning in resource management is absolutely essential.

Some members of the Government have stated that such a tax as the one envisaged in this Bill would inhibit the so-called resources boom. I think that was stated by Senator Crichton-Browne when he spoke on the tax proposed in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources on alumina. I say only that, if such a tax does inhibit a boom, that will be a good thing as most booms inevitably result in a bust sooner or later. Surely what we have to do in this country is to develop carefully our resources in the long term to ensure that enough is left over for future generations and, most importantly, that Australia is not continually straining the demands for capital. We believe that the Federal royalty payments should be abolished and that these should become part of the levy or pithead tax, as we have been advocating. State royalty payments will undoubtedly continue, as it is unlikely, in the short term at least, that the State governments will forsake them. However, in taxing mine or field production a total tax should be imposed. From the producer's point of view, it should be one figure. The Federal Government could then readily vary the revenue sharing formula between States to pick up the differentials and take note of existing State royalty payments. In summary, the Australian Democrats position is that we must oppose the Australian Labor Party amendment to introduce a super tax on profits as being impracticable in the sense of achieving anything, being inhibiting on companies and encouraging inefficiency in companies.

talk.start.para: —Senator, have you looked at the constitutional aspects of the variation in collecting tax between States?

—Yes. I believe that the constitutionality has already been demonstrated in the imposition of the levy on crude oil. It can be done. It is not an uncommon method of applying a tax on resources. I conclude simply by saying that there should be a tax on mine production of both mineral stocks and energy stocks based on world prices, the size of the field and the richness of the ore body.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —I thank all parties for their support of the Bill and wish it a speedy passage.

speech.para: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Walsh's amendment) be added.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

speech.para: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

debate.title:
CANNED FRUITS MARKETING LEGISLATION REPEAL AND AMENDMENT BILL 1982
CANNED FRUITS LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 18 March, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —The Opposition will oppose this legislation for reasons which I will state at a later stage. What the Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill 1982 and the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1982-they should be taken as a package-seek to do is to increase the levy imposed for the funding of the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation from its present 11c to 27c a basic carton which, if I remember correctly, is 24 30-ounce tins or whatever the metric equivalent is. The levy is now collected and is proposed to be collected in the future from canneries. It is sometimes disputed, in situations such as this, who actually pays the levy, whether it is the processor upon whom it is normally imposed-if only for simplicity and ease of administration-or the supplier of the product. I have always thought that because of the way markets for such agricultural products are structured there has never really been any doubt that the levy is paid by the supplier of the raw material, in this case the fruit growers. But in any case it is not relevant in this instance because all the canneries are co- operatives and are therefore owned by the growers. They share in the profits or losses more or less pro rata to the amount of fruit which is processed.

speech.para: We are opposing the levy Bill because we have grave reservations about the Corporation's competence. The writing for this industry has been on the wall for some time. But it has accumulated and continued to accumulate last year huge stocks which are the immediate cause of the current crises. It is at least legitimate to ask the question whether the money currently being paid by growers to support the Corporation is substantially being wasted, let alone to ask whether the growers should increase their contributions to fund the Corporation. Amongst other things that suspicion is fostered by the fact that the Corporation , despite the desperate position the industry is in failed to lodge a submission before the current Industries Assistance Commission inquiry, unless that situation has changed in the last couple of weeks: This leads in turn to the further question: Is the Corporation so bereft of ideas about the industry's problems or so bereft of understanding the industry's problems that it has nothing to say to the IAC? If that assumption is wrong, that is, that the Corporation is justifying the financial support it is receiving compulsorily from growers, we submit that at least for the present the Government ought to pay the increased costs of funding the Corporation.

A government which can find $300,000 to finance a propaganda campaign for its discredited housing policy in a last ditch attempt to save a discredited, decaying Liberal government in Victoria ought to be able to find a lesser amount of money for the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation. This Government allows its department of propaganda, which it euphemistically calls the Government Information Unit, to have apparently open-ended access to the public purse for the employment of loyal toadies of the Liberal Party such as Mr Verbickis for such worthy activities as spying on the challenger of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-Mr Peacock-and reporting very promptly back to the Prime Minister, as if that has anything to do with communicating to the public information in which it has some interest and an entitlement to know about. This of course, is the ostensible reason for the existence of the Government Information Unit. It employs loyal toadies, such as Mr Verbickis, to spy on the Prime Minister's rivals for the deputy leadership of the party and promptly report back.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President I take a point of order. This is all very interesting and I am sure the Senate is fascinated, but it has very little to do with the Bill before the Senate.
—I ask Senator Walsh to confine his remarks to the Bill.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I had finished making the point anyway but with your indulgence I would like to explain the relevance of it. The point the Opposition is making in opposing this Bill is that at least for the time being-regardless of whether the Government disagrees with us or is satisfied that our reservations or doubts about the worth of the Corporation are groundless-it ought to fund the increased requirements of the Corporation from general revenue, given that the Government seems to be able to find any amount of revenue to fund the activities of people such as Mr Verbickis. So I think the point I was making does have some relevance to the Bill. If, as John Kerin said in the House of Representatives when the Bill was discussed there two months ago , the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation improves on its past record we, that is the Australian Labor Party, will review our attitude as to whether growers ought to pay an increased levy to fund the Corporation's operations.

speech.para: As I mentioned earlier, the industry is at present in a state of crisis. There is a gross oversupply. Orchards are producing fruit which cannot be sold at anything near its production cost and, in the process of producing that fruit, are contributing quite significantly to the saline pollution of the Murray River and much of its valley. That absurd situation is the end product over 30 of the last 33 years of Country Party dominated coalition Government policies. It is a sad testimony to the party which claims to have real expertise in this area.

speech.speaker: Archer Sen B.R.

talk.start.para: —Unlike Senator Walsh, I support the legislation and what it proposes to do. There has been a quite considerable delay since the Bill passed through the House of Representatives on 18 February. However, the position is clearer now that the canning season has concluded. I am surprised that the Opposition is still opposed to the legislation. That opposition is certainly contrary to the industry's position and requests and it is in spite of the advice that has been obtained from the industry and from the best sources available. At the time we last got close to debating this matter-I think it was on 23 March-I received communications from the growers in South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria. I think it would be appropriate for the wishes and desires of the growers to be presented. From the Victorians I received a telex which stated:

speech.para: The Senate will shortly be taking a decision in relation to an amendment of the Australian Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill 1982 and the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1982.
This organisation which represents all canning fruit growers in Australia is fully aware and totally supports the matters which are the subject of these amendment Bills.
In particular, growers express unanimous support for the increase in the canned fruit levy from 11c to 27c per basic carton.
These levies are paid by canners and are used by the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation to fund its operations and to promote Australian canned fruits on all markets.
This levy is collected at a per basic carton rate on production in each fruit season, such seasons covering the period December through April in each.
It is imperative that the levy be collected and provided to the Corporation to enable it to carry out its vital role within the industry.

We reiterate that the levy increase has the full support of the growing sector of the industry and any move by senators to amend or reject the Bills as they stand would be contrary to the wishes of the industry concerned and viewed most unfavourably by that industry.
We would be obliged if you could ensure that the Bills concerned are passed without amendment.
Yours faithfully,
Phillip D. Marshall Secretary Australian Canning Fruitgrowers Association.
On the same day I received a telex from South Australia which reads:

I refer Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1982. SA Canning Fruitgrowers Association seeks passing of Bill without amendments urgently. Any individuals objection must be based on lack of understanding. Failure of this Bill would be calamitous for industry.
Deakin Chairman
A telex from New South Wales stated:

Subject Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1982. The Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1982 legislation has the unqualified support of NSW Canning Fruit Growers Association. Imperative that the Bill as it stands is passed without amendment as a matter of urgency.
Sam Catanzariti Chairman NSW Canning Fruit Growers Association

I do not know what advice has been obtained that would give members of the Australian Labor Party the impression that they know more about the canned fruits industry at the moment than do the growers. Senator Walsh rightly summed up the situation by saying that it does not really matter whether we say that the growers should pay the levy or that the processors should pay the levy because, as the growers run the co-operatives and the co-operatives comprise the growers, it is all the same anyway. Which pocket the levy comes out of is neither here nor there, but it is the wish of the total industry that this money be provided. There is no dissension from the top to the bottom of the industry as to the necessity for the amount of money that is being sought. There are only four processors-one in South Australia, one in New South Wales and two in Victoria. They all handle similar lines of fruit and operate at the same time of the year. They all agree that it is imperative for their survival that they be able to fund their operations in this way. It is not government funding; it is not a government tax. It is industry money and it is spent by the industry. The only way in which government is connected with it is that it is raised by government authority.

The intake question is important. It is a fact that this year's intake figure is only 50 per cent in round figures of last year's figure, because of the very poor selling season in 1981. The levy is to cover the 1982 crop all of which, as I have said, is already harvested and canned. Last year there was a surplus of about 2,500,000 unsold cases. This year about 4,000,000 cases will be processed, leaving a total of about 6,500,000 for sale throughout the year. Last year some 8,000,000 cases were processed and only a portion of that number was sold. This year, with 4,000,000 cases having been processed, 6,500,000 should be adequate to meet what the requirements look like being. Although half the amount of fruit has been processed this year in comparison to last year the costs of promotion and of running the organisation will be similar to those of last year. If only half the amount of fruit has been processed the levy naturally will have to be double what it was last year. I think that would be fairly obvious to anybody.

Last time the legislation was before the Parliament it was said that one of the reasons for objecting to it was that it represented taxing something that had already happened, that we were going to delve back and raise a levy from 1 January. That was alleged to be a very bad thing. I think the fact that the legislation was not passed by the time that the fruit started to be picked is neither here nor there. We are still talking about the 1982 crop and the need for running the industry through to next season. For instance, as from 4 April of this year the industry has been running a $350,000 advertising program in Sydney. Advertisements have appeared on television, in magazines and so on. This money is absolutely necessary for the industry to be able to maximise its sales in its own markets. The levy of 27c per basic carton, in case it has not been made clear, is a doubling of the 11c provided by the previous legislation for advertising, plus 3c for promotion and 2c for administration. The amount of 27c is accepted as being adequate to assist this industry, which is struggling very hard, to survive.

The industry is doing everything it can to improve its position. I think its management, organisation and operation are doing it considerable credit. I think it certainly does nobody any good to try to cry it down at a time when it is in extreme difficulties for a whole variety of reasons, very few of which are its own responsibility. I thought that Senator Walsh's comment that, if the legislation were not passed now and it was shown to be necessary, the Opposition would review it later was really a very inadequate remark. Of course, if the legislation is not passed now there will not be any later. If the industry goes broke as of now for failure to get the funds that are necessary for it to survive until next month then I point out to Senator Walsh that I am afraid that waiting for another Bill to come in so that we can consider it will be of very little value.

For the Opposition to say that it is not approving because it lacks confidence in the organisation again is looking for an easy way out when the organisation that is there represents every grower in this industry in Australia. They are all represented, every one of them. They have made their decisions. They have appointed the best people possible. They have obtained the best advice they can get. Whilst I as a Tasmanian have no direct influence on the industry in New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria-not one of those gentlemen engaged in the industry is an elector of mine-I have been to the growing areas on several occasions. I have done everything I can to try to provide assistance where possible. I will continue to do so. I certainly trust that we can pass this legislation, which is what the industry requires, without any fiddling, fuddling or taking a stance. I hope we can pass the legislation forthwith. I support the Bills.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the legislation. Our initial reservations in relation to one of the Bills concerned clause 4 which imposes a retrospective tax as from 1 January 1982. I do not accept that retrospective tax is a problem--
—It is a levy, not a tax.

—I thank Senator Archer. I do not accept that a retrospective levy is a problem of this chamber. It is a problem of the Government in terms of arranging its own legislative program. Nevertheless, this levy has been supported, as Senator Archer has already pointed out, by all sections of the industry, not only by the Australian Canners' Association-the producers-but also by the Australian Canning Fruitgrowers Association and its State affiliates. The fact that those various bodies are unanimous in supporting an increase in the levy from 11c to 27c a basic carton I believe must be taken note of if one is to be concerned about retrospective legislation. The principal objection to retrospective legislation is the imposition of a penalty backwards, whereas if it were not retrospective legislation that penalty would not have been applied. I think that principle, however, does not apply in this case because the people who will be affected by that are in agreement with having that levy imposed upon them. Therefore, we will not be pressing any amendment in relation to retrospectivity in regard to this piece of legislation, although in general we will be opposed, as always, to retrospective legislation that does not have that type of unanimous support from the people upon whom the legislation will be imposed.

speech.para: The industry wishes to make use of the levy and, as Senator Archer has already pointed out, it will not amount to very much more than what happened in the 1981 canning season. The canning season traditionally stretching from Christmas to a little into April has, in most cases, now concluded. However, the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation has already embarked on its advertising program, presumably spending money that it hopes to receive from the passing of this piece of legislation. I think that is an unfortunate position for the Corporation to be in. Indeed, I had hoped that this piece of legislation would have been passed before Parliament rose for the Easter recess. I think that with some judicious shuffling that could have been achieved. I believe it is unfortunate that the Corporation has been put into these circumstances of embarking in hope, no matter how well-grounded that hope may be.

Also, I think it has to be said in regard to this piece of legislation which bears to some extent on the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation that the Corporation's activities in the past few years have not been above criticism. Indeed, I am pleased to see that the Corporation has accepted the types of criticisms that have been levelled against it and, in its own reorganisation, has sought to come to grips with the problems, some of which have been of its own making in the last two or three years. I think the Senate certainly wishes to give every support to our rural industries of which the fruit growing industry is probably one of the best examples in terms of problems that we are running into, particularly as it is not one of the industries we could expect in the foreseeable future to have a bright and profitable outlook. Its markets are not secure and all projections are that the Corporation must look more and more to the domestic market to satisfy its output. We hope that the money from the increased levy that the Corporation will be using will be put to good use and that the employment of that levy will, indeed, at least secure the industry as it is now operating and will mean that it is in a viable position. We hope that if at any stage in the future new markets do appear-of course, part of this levy will be used to try to expand those export markets-the Corporation will be in a position to take advantage of those markets. We will be supporting the Bill.

speech.speaker: McLaren Sen G.T.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill in a cognate debate with the Canned Fruits Marketing Legislation Repeal and Amendment Bill which relates to the marketing of canned fruits. I will confine my remarks to the Canned Fruits Levy Amendment Bill. I agree with my colleague, Senator Walsh, who said that we will be opposing the imposition of this increased levy. Senator Macklin who has just resumed his seat and Senator Archer said that the levy would assist the industry, but I am not yet convinced that this levy will in any way assist the industry. As a matter of fact, it will have a detrimental effect on the industry. Despite the fact that the canneries are co-operatives, the growers just do not have the wherewithal to withstand the onslaught of this increased levy.

speech.para: Senator Archer in his opening remarks quoted some correspondence which he had received from various officials of the industry in the various States. He quoted correspondence he had received from Mr Deakin, the Chairman of the Riverland Canning Fruitgrowers Association, but I did not hear him cite the date when that correspondence was sent to him. I must have missed that. I would very much doubt whether the date of that correspondence was after the recent hearings of the Industries Assistance Commission into the Australian canned fruit industry. My understanding is that Mr Deakin came away from that inquiry after having listened to the Chairman of the Commission castigate in no uncertain terms the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation for the way it conducts its business. I also have not received any communication from people in the Riverland saying that the growers in the Riverland were ever called together to have a meeting to discuss this increased levy. I do not know with what authority Mr Deakin sent that correspondence. He certainly did not send any to me as a South Australian although, apparently, he sent correspondence to people on the Government side. I , as a member representing South Australia, have had no communication. Of course , Mr Deakin under the charter of the Riverland Canning Fruitgrowers Association may be able to call an executive meeting and make a decision. One of my colleagues in the other place in speaking to this legislation said:
Growers in the Riverland have been contacting us continuously complaining that they cannot get their leaders to convene a meeting with them so that they can express their concern.

I have no information that in fact a meeting of growers was convened. I am at a loss to say whether Mr Deakin was speaking on behalf of the executive of that association or whether he was speaking on behalf of the growers. I will try to ascertain that next week. I agree with the other speakers in the debate who said that the canned fruit industry-I will refer only to the industry in my own State because I am more conversant with it-has been going through very traumatic times for many years. Whilst this Government has been prepared at various stages to make loans available, the loans do not get these people out of trouble. I well remember that when we were in government and the former Senator Wriedt was Minister for Agriculture we saw that loans would not help the people; so we converted over $1m, I think, of a Commonwealth loan to a direct grant to try to help the industry. Likewise, the South Australian Labor Government, under the premiership of Mr Dunstan, also converted a loan to a grant to endeavour to help the industry. I noticed in today's Advertiser that the South Australian Government has now made $280,000 by way of aid available to the Riverland growers. An article in today's Advertiser states in part:
The chairman of the SA Canning Fruit Growers' Association, Mr J. Deakin, said the announcement was 'fairly disappointing' and most growers considered the loans a non-event.
Growers had hoped for Government grants to ease their plight.
In February growers threatened not to pick peaches and pears unless the SA Government agreed to pay more than the new minimum prices fixed by the Fruit Industry Sugar Concession Committee.
The prices were $180 a tonne delivered for peaches and $130 a tonne for pears, a reduction on last year's prices of $45 a tonne and $30 a tonne respectively.
The growers said the lower prices combined with reduced tonnages to be processed under quota would mean they would receive only about 40 per cent of their previous year's income.

We have evidence from Mr Deakin himself that the stone fruit growers in the Riverland area of South Australia in a desperate plight. Not only will they be in a desperate plight, but also small business and local government will be in a desperate plight. I have received correspondence from the Riverland Local Government Association expressing its grave concern as to what will happen if the growers embark upon a treepull scheme, as a result of which production will drop even though at present we do not have a market. I understand that something like four million cartons of canned fruit, a carryover from last year's season, are in store and cannot be sold. There is a problem also in South Africa where there is a glut crop. South Africa is eating into some of the markets in which we hope to gain some recognition.

I am somewhat surprised, in view of the fact that the Riverland Local Government Association would have written to members of the Federal Parliament who represent South Australia and who expressed their concern, that not one South Australian senator from the Government side has spoken in the debate on this legislation. It might be that Government senators had their fingers burnt a few years ago when Senator Teague spoke on the brandy excise which was increased by about 83 per cent. He is on record as saying that he would not be a credible Liberal if he did not voice his objection to what harm that impost would create for the grape growers in the Riverland. When the crunch came, Senator Teague, like all his colleagues, voted for the legislation, and that has had a detrimental effect in the Riverland. That might well be why we do not hear any South Australian senators speaking about the plight of the industry and voicing their concern. It has been left to Senator Archer, the sole Government speaker, to represent the Government.

talk.start.para: —He is a strong one.

—The Government Whip said that he is a strong speaker, but of course Senator Archer did admit that he represents a State which has no financial interest at all in the canned fruit industry because fruit is not canned in Tasmania. I do not know why Senator Archer was put up as a stop-gap speaker. I am not criticising what he said. At least he admitted that he comes from a State which has no problems with canned fruit. The State that has the very serious problems is not represented in this debate by a speaker from the Government side showing some concern about these people in the Riverland. I received a letter from Mr E. J. Commane, the Secretary of the Riverland Local Government Association. Accompanying this letter is a copy of a submission that the Local Government Association made to the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry. The person who was handling this submission was Mr Donald Rex Elliott from Waikerie, a fruit grower. He said that the submission was presented on behalf of the Riverland Local Government Association whose members are the district Councils of Barmera, Berri, Loxton, Morgan, Paringa and Waikerie and the Corporation of the Town of Renmark. That document clearly sets out all the problems which the Local Government Association considers will arise if the canned fruit industry in South Australia collapses. Of course we all know that the cannery at Berri is in receivership at present. I could speak for an hour as to what caused a lot of the problems there in the last couple of fruit seasons, but time does not permit me to do that. A detailed outline of the problems besetting the industry is set out in the last year's December issue of the State of Agriculture which is a monthly report issued by the Department of Agriculture in South Australia. I will not quote the article now because time does not permit. In the February issue there is further reference to the problems associated with the industry. Again in this month's issue we find further mention of the canned fruit peach harvest. A small paragraph states:

speech.para: The canning peach harvest now completed resulted in a final cannery intake of 5 ,400 tonnes, just over the target quota. Quality was fair to good, but recovery rates were somewhat lower than last season. Final intakes were on 24 March.

We know the quota for this season was well below what could have been delivered had the growers had a market for their fruit. Unfortunately, that market does not exist. There was one stage, after the quota had been set, when the cannery thought it may not get enough fruit to fill the quota. Of course a lot of the fruit that was available was not suitable or was not wanted at that time. It was certainly suitable for canning, but the cannery did not want to take that in and at one stage it looked as though it would fall short of the quota. As pointed out in the State of Agriculture journal the industry exceeded its quota by a small margin.

I should like to advise the Senate that the Labor Party in South Australia is very concerned and has been concerned for many years. It has done its best, in more ways than one to try to assist the industry in the Riverland. Through our previous Minister for Agriculture, who is now the shadow Minister, we have done everything possible to try to assist the industry.
