2. Introduction

This submission is concerned with adjustment assistance for cannery fruitgrowers, canneries and cannery workers affected by the market downturn for canned fruits. Other submissions will explore the extent of the market downturn and the degree of adjustment that will be necessary in the industry. We have addressed ourselves to the problems of adjustment within the rural communities engaged in growing and processing fruit for the industry. We have assumed from our discussion with other parties to the enquiry that the reduction in the industry will be substantial.
3. Need for additional adjustment assistance
Pressures for adjustment in agriculture can be divided into adjustment-push and adjustment-pull.

Adjustment-push occurs when prices are depressed, production cannot be sold and payments are delayed. This history of the canning fruit industry over the last decade shows that there has been no lack of adjustment-push pressure on growers to leave the industry.

Adjustment-pull is provided by industries that are prosperous and that attract growers with their opportunity for greater profit. The winegrape growing industry provided considerable adjustment-pull in the early 1970s but has now lost this due to excessive production and discounting at the retail level.

The traditional horticultural industries cannot provide adequate adjustment- pull for the canning fruit industry. Additional assistance is needed to foster new industries and crops to provide the necessary adjustment-pull. The present rural adjustment scheme only provides for the change from one established industry to another and is inadequate when new industries have to be developed.
4. Justification for additional adjustment assistance
The lack of alternative enterprises which provide adjustment-pull is slowing down the rate of adjustment in the canning fruit industry. This slow rate of adjustment is causing:
4.1 Severe hardship to growers, workers and rural communities that are dependent on the canning fruit industry.

4.2 Low profits on fruitgrowing blocks and extra cost to the community. Drainage and irrigation rates do not pay the full cost of the community investment in the irrigation and drainage infrastructure. Additional contribution to this commitment is only obtained if growers are profitable enough to pay tax.
We believe that these reasons are sufficient to justify additional adjustment assistance.
5. Short Term measures

The most severe impost on growers and the local communities will be during 1982 when it is likely that nearly half of the fruit produced will be surplus to market requirements. Short term assistance can be provided to growers through carry-on loans but without further long term measures these are not likely to be taken up by growers on a large scale.
Unless growers are able to answer the question 'carry on for what?' they are not likely to commit themselves to further borrowing even at favourable rates of interest.

Carry-on loans can be extremely successful (see Appendix I) where they are provided in a form that meets the farmers needs, where they have been 'sold' to the rural community as an acceptable management tool, and where there is a long term future for the enterprise that is being supported by the carry-on loan.

These conditions were met during the 1975-77 drought in SA where $23m of carry- on loans were provided to 1300 farm families. The winegrape carry-on loan scheme provides a contrast. The major portion of funds provided have not been used because growers could see no reason to continue borrowing while their future markets remained unsure. The winegrape carry-on scheme was only available to keep growers in the business of winegrape growing. To be effective in the canning fruit industry carry-on loans would have to be linked with long term measures that allowed growers to answer the question 'carry-on for what?' with optimism.
6. Long term measures
6.1 Adjustment-push
The depressing future prospects and the history of uncertainty in the canning fruit industry provide strong incentives to growers to leave the industry.

This adjustment-push pressure can be reinforced through assistance in the form of tree pull grants for growers to reduce productive capacity. We do not believe that this measure alone will provide an adequate incentive for adjustment to take place at a desirable rate but we believe it should be provided.

Tree pull assistance provides an immediate and tangible form of assistance which demonstrates concern for the problems of the growers. We recommend its adoption as part of a package of measures designed to improve the rate of adjustment.

As explained in Appendix 1 the SA Government continued to provide drought assistance through measures such as freight subsidies which were considered a marginal value because to withdraw such assistance would have removed psychological support to the community and increased levels of stress.
It should be remembered that the process of adjustment is not merely a relocation of physical resources but includes a whole community. Adjustment puts that community under stress.
6.2 Adjustment-pull

Without alternative crops or enterprise for growers to develop on land now devoted to canning fruit tree pull alone will not provide sufficient incentive. The rate of adjustment will be slow and the hardship created in the community very considerable. There is no single traditional crop or enterprise that can provide sufficient adjustment-pull for all canning fruit growers.

The citrus industry is currently the most profitable established alternative but the large area of citrus coming into production over the next few years is a cause of concern and sufficient reason not to encourage further expansion in that industry. Winegrape growers have been told that over production and discounting will lead to a reduction of winegrape acreage in the near future. The solution must be to provide a range of new crops and enterprises that can as a group provide the adjustment-pull that is required by those growers forced to quit the canning fruit industry. The present rural adjustment scheme is not well suited to fostering new crops or enterprises and we recommended changes on the following basis:
6.2.1 The Present Scheme

Originally the rural adjustment scheme was introduced to assist the wheat-sheep industry that was going through a period of severe marketing crisis in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Debt reconstruction and farm build up were the two forms of assistance available. Later it was argued that farm build up was not always appropriate in horticultural areas where two run down blocks would be twice as unprofitable as one. A more appropriate strategy would be to redevelop a block to raise productivity levels through replanting, better irrigation, etc. This form of assistance was included in the scheme in the mid 1970s.
6.2.2 Eligibility

Currently the rural adjustment scheme occupies the marginal area of rural finance as a lender of last resort. To be eligible for rural adjustment loans it is necessary for the applicant to be refused funds from commercial borrowers. The applicant has to be assessed as commercially viable before the application is approved.

The result is that the present scheme caters for the marginal groups of producers whose enterprises do not produce a profit at commercial rates of interest but can show a profit at concessional rates of interest. A grower with a declining rate of profit from a property must show considerable judgment on the timing of lodging an application. Some growers have been refused assistance on the grounds that funds could be obtained commercially and as little as a year later have been refused on the grounds that their enterprise is not commercially profitable even with concessional loans.

We recommend that this eligibility criteria is removed for the canning fruit industry. This could be done by amending the relevant State and Commonwealth Acts to allow for the proclamation of 'Priority Adjustment Areas' in which the scheme could operate without the requirement that the applicant is first refused by a commercial lender. Such a proclamation would be regularly reviewed and revoked when the special adjustment needs of the industry had been met. Such a procedure already exists for invoking the carry-on loan provisions of the Act.

We do not expect that such a relaxation of the eligibility criteria will result in a great flood of applications. The depressed state of the industry makes it very unattractive to commercial lenders and is not difficult for growers to obtain the refusal of their bankers. Such refusal does have however an adverse effect on their confidence and they feel that it gives them a community image of a failed producer.
By making them directly eligible for finance their confidence to go into other activities is better and they avoid the humiliation of a commercial refusal.

An additional advantage of this proposal is that it would allow the State Department of Agriculture officials the opportunity of 'selling' to growers a complete adjustment package which included finance. Currently they provide mainly technical advice on how to change from one enterprise to another. Their role in encouraging adjustment would be greatly strengthened if they could carry their involvement to the financial aspects of adjustment planning for individual growers. We believe that the need for 'selling' funds has not been given sufficient emphasis by administration of rural adjustment schemes and the lack of 'selling' explains why the demand for loans, in spite of their comparatively low interest rates, has in many cases been surprisingly low.
6.2.3 Types of Assistance

Currently rural adjustment assistance is provided in the form of loans with long term and concessional interest rates. This is adequate where the adjustment is to a traditional industry where returns are reasonably predictable-at least.

We have already said that these traditional industries have no room for those who must adjust out of canning fruit production. In the case of new developments , which we believe are essential to provide the canning fruit growers with adequate adjustment-pull, the returns may be high but the risks are also high. Growers will be reluctant to adjust to a new enterprise unless the risk can be reduced. They fear the possibility of repaying a loan over many years from the profits of their remaining enterprises when the loan was taken out originally to launch a new enterprise which subsequently crashed. This would be particularly true of smaller growers and is common throughout the world where risk minimisation is often more important than profit maximisation.
We recommend the following changes to the Rural Adjustment program:

(a) Loans for farm improvement and debt reconstruction. Currently this is the section of the rural adjustment programme that is of major significance to horticultural producers. Long term loans are provided at concessional rates of interest under this scheme.

We believe that the subsidy component of the scheme should be re-arranged to provide much greater benefits to the grower in the early years of the loan and fewer in the later years. This could be done by providing 'suspensory' loans in which the interest in the early years is subsidised to an extremely low level or remitted altogether and the capital repayments are postponed. In later years the interest reverts to normal commercial rates and the loan is subjected to five- yearly reviews which can result in a speeding up of the rate of repayment.

(b) Risk sharing arrangements for new ventures. We recommend that the authority should have power to make arrangements with growers to share risk on an equity participation basis. These agreements would be similar to sharefarming arrangements. The major difference would be that NET returns would be shared between grower and authority, not GROSS returns as is the practice with current sharefarming arrangements. In most cases we anticipate the grower would supply land, labour and water to the partnership while the authority would provide working capital required to equal the agreed value of the grower's resource contribution. Any capital required over and above that amount would be contributed equally.
There should be provision for the grower to buy the authority out at any time on an agreed basis.

(c) Market Development Financial Assistance. The development of new crops and enterprises that are needed to provide adjustment-pull is closely related to the development of markets. In some cases domestic markets already exist and are supplied by imports.

The replacement of these imports can be a simple marketing exercise if Australian production prices are competitive. A notable recent example of such an exercise is the development of an industry now providing coriander seed for local and export market. However in many cases, any replacement of imported canned fruit and other lines will require effort to be put both into production and marketing simultaneously and therefore the authority should not be precluded from providing funds for market development.

We recommend that the funds should be provided to merchants or co-operatives willing to develop such markets on the same basis as they are to growers-i.e. either 'suspensory' loans, or a share the risk/share the profit basis.
6.2.4 Administration

We recommend that the administration of the modified rural adjustment scheme should be carried out on a regional basis. This would give administrators a better understanding of regional problems and make the scheme more accessible to growers.
We suggest the following administrative structure:

* Regional Enterprise Board consisting of three part-time members to decide applications for loans, sharefarming agreements and market development schemes. Membership of the Board would change fully every three years.

* Support group of assessors and financial managers to investigate applications for decision by the Board and to manage applications that are approved. This simple administrative structure could be achieved by redeploying existing positions involved in the administration of rural adjustment. The major difficulty would be the selection of suitable personnel to fill those positions. Currently the Rural Assistance Branch lacks the capacity to assess innovative new developments and it is difficult to find suitable people within the public service. The assessment of marketing projects poses even greater difficulties as Australia is notoriously poor at marketing agricultural produce. It would probably be necessary to recruit staff from overseas-possibly New Zealand which has had remarkable success in developing and marketing new horticultural crops.
7. Cannery adjustment

The adjustment problems of the canning fruit industry cannot be solved purely at the production of fruit level. The problem extends to the processing sector of the industry where depressed levels of throughput substantially increase the share of overheads paid by each unit of production.

As growers receive the residual amount after processing costs any further decline in the industry. It is quite possible that the industry could enter a downward spiral in which each increase in costs and retail prices would reduce market demand and so reduce production even further.
There are a number of options:

(a) One option would be to close one cannery and process the fruit through the remaining canneries at high levels of throughput. This has already occurred in South Australia. The JON cannery in Adelaide was closed and the production transferred to the RIVERLAND cannery.
As both South Australia and New South Wales only have one cannery each now, Victoria should act to ease the problem of rationalisation facing the whole industry.

(b) Another option is to diversify into other products to spread the overheads over a larger overall production. This has been done by some canneries but the scope for further diversification into 'other' products is limited.

(c) Reduction of overheads is a further option that should be considered. This option needs to be examined further for the Riverland cannery. By putting the cannery into receivership, the South Australian government has substantially reduced the capital overhead of the cannery which is now valued at $2 1/4m. The effect of this on the total overheads should be examined.
7.1 Redundancy payments for cannery workers

Faced with a situation where a decline in cannery production is inevitable we recommend that compensation be paid to workers made redundant by adjustment in the processing of canned fruit. We believe that it is inequitable that the Rural Adjustment Scheme should be providing 'non repayable' loans to growers who voluntarily adjust out of horticulture while equivalent assistance is not available to workers who are equal victims of the same economic pressures. We recommend that the present provision of 'non repayable' loans be extended to workers in the cannery.
7.2 Regional employment

The rural communities which will suffer from the downward adjustment in the canning fruit industry provide limited alternative employment opportunities. Decentralisation of industry and employment has not been strikingly successful in Australia and in any case is beyond the scope of this inquiry. We do, however , believe there are some opportunities for agro-based processing in the region that would provide alternative employment to displaced workers.

The opportunities for each industry may be small but collectively they could provide a substantial number of jobs. We recommend that the Regional Enterprise Boards be given sufficient powers and funds to invest in downstream processing that flows from new enterprises they foster in the growing sector. For example if they assisted a herbal tea growing industry or flower and vegetable seed production industry, they should be able to assist the establishment of local packing plants for those products.
8. Confidence in the canning fruit industry

With the depressing market projection for the industry and the substantial reduction of production that will have to take place to balance supply with profitable market requirements, there is a danger that the residual industry will lose more ground than is necessary because of a lack of confidence in its future.
8.1 Canning Fruit Corporation
Now that the Canning Fruit Corporation has been given wide powers over the marketing of canning fruit it must be looked at critically and performance benefitting the industry must be demanded.
8.1.1 Foreign Imports

We are concerned at the apparent indifference of the Canning Fruit Corporation and its canning industry members to the successful penetration of the Australian domestic market by Californian, Italian, Dutch and French products. These products could be easily produced in Australia if the Australian industry had the inclination to develop the expertise. A recent example of foreign penetration where we already have the expertise is Leetona brand canned tomatoes grown and processed in Italy seen in supermarkets in August 1981. A visit to suburban supermarkets and ethnic food shops will show shelves of 'specially' canned and bottled fruit from California (in particular) and European sources selling to Australian consumers at premium prices.
8.1.2 Pack Quality

An opinion gained from discussing the matter with consumers indicates that the quality of the fruit pack currently sold on domestic markets as sugar free should be upgraded. Without added sugar, the lack of flavour of the fruit becomes obvious. This lack of flavour is due to the degree of ripeness of fruit delivered for processing. At present firm fruit is demanded and sugar content is low. We recommend that sugar free packs be continued, but that fruit quality be lifted. The present requirement for delivery of 'firm' (that is, slightly coloured) fruit relates to ease of handling. Alternative methods of handling will be required if the prime fruit necessary to better consumer levels of acceptance is to be provided. Falling sales on domestic markets often mean that the consumer has lost interest in the product for negative reasons. Talking to consumers will readily reveal consumer attitudes and enable production and marketing adjustments to be developed. This exercise should be part of the CFC responsibility.
8.1.3 Penetration of export markets

Australian canners have failed to penetrate the markets of the Arabian Gulf and the Middle East. Our observations of these markets show that a major reason has been poor presentation of canned fruit to these markets and a lack of market research. There are some very successful Australian exporters to these markets such as Anchor Foods and Sarah Lee. We believe the Canning Fruit Corporation should allow companies such as these with a proven performance on these export markets to act as agents for Australian canned fruit. This would require a relaxation of the Corporation's policy on agencies and would no doubt require permission to be given to allow the agents to sell canned fruit under their own label. We believe that greater efforts in these markets would be more worthwhile than the current futile effort to sell canned fruit to EEC countries for a profit. It should be noted that when Spain and Greece take up mooted EEC membership the competition in terms of production will be greatly increased. In view of the EEC situation, the decision to send five members of the Canning Fruit Corporation to a trade fair in Hamburg should at least be matched with a similar expenditure in market exploration in North Africa, the Middle East and the Arabian Gulf.

It should not be thought, however, that these Arab markets will provide a potential bonanza, nor should their potential be used as an excuse for postponing adjustment decisions. Markets will only be developed with patient and persistent effort. If a market is developed and further production is required, this could be supplied from the re-development of the residual fruit producing areas where productivity has fallen due to lack of confidence among growers.
9. Research capacity

The quality of canned fruit from Australian canneries needs to be improved and new products developed which take account of the growing concern within the community about excessive consumption of sugar. The quality of the domestic pack also needs improvement so that canners can retain the domestic market which has become increasingly important to the industry as the export market has diminished. The industry cannot afford to ignore the high priced market for ' special' products packed in glass, for instance, that is currently supplied by imports. There is some evidence that these products are expanding the market for processed fruits to consumers who would not otherwise purchase canned fruit products. In putting forward this area of concern we are drawing a parallel with the Australian cheese industry where foreign imports succeed because of the unwillingness of Australian manufacturers to produce various types of cheese.
In order to successfully carry out a strategy of competing with foreign imports , it will be necessary to expand the research capacity into canned fruit.

A full scale research institute modelled on the Wine Research Institute is probably not justified but we do recommend that the canneries and the Commonwealth Government jointly provide funds to CSIRO or colleges of technology to train cannery managers in the technology necessary to produce products similar to the imported special lines currently on the market. When the Australian industry has caught up with technology advances overseas further research would be justified.

He indicated a strong preference to have a new Royal Commission established for this purpose.

As the House has been informed by the Prime Minister on many occasions, the Government envisaged at the establishment of the Stewart Royal Commission, the possibility of an extension of its terms of reference to cover other drug trafficking groups. It felt that this approach ought to be tested before any consideration was given to the possibility of a new Royal Commission. The Minister for Administrative Services wrote to Mr Justice Stewart informing him of developments and the House resolved to send the Hansard of the debate to the Royal Commissioner. Furthermore, the Commonwealth's law officers were asked by the Prime Minister to examine the documents which Mr Hayden tabled in the House on 25 March and the allegations concerning Nugan Hand made in the House and the Senate, as well as a letter to the Prime Minister from Mr Hayden, with a view to ascertaining whether the matters raised warranted an extension of the Stewart Royal Commission's terms of reference.
The Law Officers have formed the opinion that an extension of the terms of reference of the Royal Commission is warranted to cover allegations of:
Nugan Hand's involvement in drug dealing, beyond any association with the Clark group;
Nugan Hand's laundering of money, and association with organised crime;
interference with earlier investigation of Nugan Hand.

Having regard to the nature of the matters identified by the Law Officers as requiring further investigation and their relation to matters already under investigation by the Stewart Royal Commission, the Government does not think it appropriate that a new Commission should be established. A further inquiry into these matters will be best handled by the Stewart Commission under extended terms of reference.

Extension of the Royal Commission's terms of reference to cover Nugan Hand would be consistent with our announcement on establishing the Commission that the terms of reference might need to be supplemented to cover other drug trafficking groups.

It is also consistent with the need for a wide and impartial inquiry into all aspects touching Nugan Hand, including those reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 March 1982 of evidence given to investigators that Nugan Hand supported and was used by persons and organisations across the political spectrum. There is a need for even-handedness in action to be taken by the Government in this matter.

The Government has made a decision, subject of course to the views of States who have granted concurrent Commissions, that the terms of reference for the Stewart Commission should be extended as recommended by the Law Officers.

The Prime Minister has written to the Premiers of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland to seek their support in principle to the proposed extension of the terms of reference. The letter raised the need for agreement by at least New South Wales of a parallel extension of its Commission to consider breaches of State Law.

The Government has noted the Law Officer's conclusion that the need for a specific inquiry into any foreign intelligence agency links has not been established. There have been firm United States denials about CIA involvement with Nugan Hand. The Government intends, however, that the extended terms of reference will be wide enough to allow the Commission to investigate Nugan Hand links with any organisation. The Commonwealth has always taken the view that all persons involved in criminal activities affecting Australia, regardless of whether they are members of any organisation, should be thoroughly investigated with the aim of establishing their involvement in drug trafficking or other crimes.

As the Minister had indicated to the House, the Government has had repeated assurances from the US Government that there was no connection between the CIA and Nugan Hand. On 26 March 1982 the Public Affairs Division of the CIA took the unusual step of issuing a statement responding to allegations about links between Nugan Hand and the CIA and operations by the CIA against the Labor Government. It emphatically denied those allegations. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of a cable handed to the Government by the US Embassy referring to the statement by the Public Affairs Division of the CIA.

Mr President, in response to a recommendation from Mr Justice Woodward in his Further Report into Drug Trafficking and on the Commonwealth's initiative, the terms of reference for the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking were widened to enable it to investigate the evidence concerning Nugan Hand and persons associated with it.

Volume 1 of the Joint Task Force Report deals with the activities of Murray Stewart Riley, Harry Wainwright and some related drug matters. The draft press release submitted by the Joint Task Force with Volume 1 and incorporated in Hansard by the Prime Minister on 18 March outlined the reasons why the Volume should not be made public. As foreshadowed to the House, the Prime Minister did, however, make a copy of the report available to the Leader of the Opposition.
The Commonwealth Government has now considered and accepted the recommendations in Volume 1. Specifically, the Government has:

endorsed the action proposed for the reference by the Joint Task Force of available evidence, information and relevant papers, concerning the activities of persons named, to the relevant Commonwealth and State Crown Law or other authorities so that consideration can be given to the preferment of charges or other appropriate action-such reference is, I am advised, now well in hand;

endorsed the proposed reference by the Joint Task Force of relevant information and papers-concerning drug importation routes, unregistered gaol visits, avoidance of the preventative screen by corruption, and sale and purchase of property-to the relevant Commonwealth and State authorities for appropriate action; and
agreed that Volume 1 and, where necessary, supportive material be distributed by the Joint Task Force to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and the AFP Bureau of Crime Intelligence.
A copy of Volume 1 has already been sent to the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking.

I should add that where relevant information and papers are passed to Commonwealth authorities for appropriate action, the Ministers responsible will be asked to monitor progress on necessary corrective action.
The Chairman of the Joint Management Committee has been advised of the Commonwealth Government's full endorsement of the recommendations in Volume 1.
I am informed that the New South Wales Government has taken similar action in relation to matters falling within its areas of responsibility.
Mr President, the Joint Task Force has advised that Volume 2 of its Report will deal with the Nugan Hand group of companies and their dealings with known and suspected drug trafficking groups.

The Royal Commission's extended terms of reference will ensure that it has ample scope to investigate and report on all matters of concern to Australia arising out of allegations made in relation to Nugan Hand. The Royal Commission will be assisted in its work by the decision recently announced by the Treasurer that the Government has decided to amend the income and tax law to allow it to be given information held by the Australian Tax Office.

The Prime Minister is writing to the Leader of the Opposition in the House advising him of the Government's decision on extension of ther terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission. He is informing the Leader of the Opposition that, subject to agreement of the Stewart Royal Commission and the Joint Task Force, he or his Deputy Leader may peruse the relevant files of the former Narcotics Bureau. Those files, which are in the custody of the Royal Commission and the Task Force, hold originals of documents tabled in this House by the Leader of the Opposition on 25 March 1982.

Let there be no doubt in any mind that the Government is resolute in its intention that there should be the fullest possible investigation into the allegations of unlawful activities by the Nugan Hand organisation and persons associated with it in those activities. Moreover, let there be no doubt that the extended terms of reference will make it possible for the Stewart Royal Commission to examine exhaustively all matters regarding Nugan Hand of concern to Australia.

As the House has already been informed by the Prime Minister and the Minister on a number of occasions, the Government has been open and frank in its handling of this matter and had referred all the files to either the Joint Task Force or the Stewart Royal Commission. The Prime Minister and the Minister also appealed to the House and to all persons that if they have any information or documents relating to the activities of the Nugan Hand Bank, they should come forward to produce that information and documents to either the Joint Task Force or the Steward Royal Commission. The Government repeats that appeal again today.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of the Law Officers' report.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
NUGAN HAND

Nugan Hand raised in the Representatives on 11, 16, 17, 18 and 24 March, 1982 (Hansard House of Representatives, pages 890-927, 959-960, 976-988, 1033-1034, 1127-1131 and 1313-1314). We have read as well a copy of a letter dated 25 March , 1982 relating to a re-examination of the Commission's terms of reference from the Honourable Bill Hayden to the Right Honourable Malcolm Fraser C.H. M.P.
We think that the material and allegations in the tabled documents and the passages from Hansard above set out warrant an extension of the terms of reference.

In our opinion the terms should be so drafted as clearly to authorise, for example, an inquiry by the Commissioner into the allegations of Nugan Hand's general involvement in drug dealing as opposed to such dealing only when in association with Terrence John Clark; into the allegations of a general laundering of money wrongfully obtained or wrongfully concealed from the Australian authorities and into allegations of cooperation with organised crime.

None of the papers tabled support an allegation of trafficking in arms. There is nothing to suggest public disquiet on the question. We think that in the absence of some credible evidence to suggest it or a sense of positive public disquiet the terms should not be extended to include arms trafficking.

The transcript of the television interview of a former Narcotics Bureau agent contains statements that Michael Hand was understood to be either an ''ex-CIA operative or a current CIA operative'' (Hansard House of Representatives, page 924) and that other people connected with the CIA were within the Nugan Hand organisation. The basis for this, as for similar suggestions in one of the tabled documents, nowhere appears. The imprecision of the statements and their hearsay basis hardly support an extension in this regard of the terms of reference.

Suggestions of Nugan Hand's involvement with foreign intelligence agencies have appeared from time to time in the Press. The sensational nature of the allegation is, no doubt, in part responsible. But apart from allegations in the tabled papers of Michael Hand's and Bernard Houghton's association (in the main spoken of in the past) with foreign intelligence services, there is no real evidence to support Nugan Hand's involvement. The additional reference to a retired United States Admiral (former head of an Intelligence Group with which Hand of Houghton or both had worked) as employed by Nugan Hand or a subsidiary does not carry the matter further. Nor do references to attendance at meetings called for commercial purposes of retired high ranking members of the United States Defence forces. Their engagement in commerce is hardly unusual.

While it is open to the Government to extend the terms to include Nugan Hand's alleged involvement or cooperation in its illegal activities with foreign intelligence agencies, on the present material we are unable to advise it to do so.

Mr Hayden's letter says ''it is essential the Commission enquire into allegations that Government officials and/or Ministers inhibited or attempted to inhibit investigations into all or some Nugan Hand activities''. Material which could suggest such action by a Government official, although not by Ministers, is contained in the papers tabled by Mr Hayden and allegations to that effect have been made in the Representatives and during a television interview, the transcript of which is incorporated in Hansard (H. of R.) of 11 March, 1982 at p . 924. The terms of reference, we think, should be extended to include this allegation.

Whether they should also extend to allegations concerning Ministers is more doubtful. The suggestion is that some Minister other than the then responsible Minister gave the direction to confine the investigation. The issues would therefore be, was any such direction given, and, if so, by which Minister from amongst all those in the Ministry? It is open to serious doubt whether general allegations of this gravity against, in effect, any, perhaps each, member of the Ministry should be submitted to a Royal Commissioner. Nonetheless, the terms should be widened, as we have said, to include whether a Government official improperly sought to confine the investigations. A term of reference raising the question whether any person improperly interefered with, or sought to confine, the investigation would allow inquiry into whether a Government official did so as well as permitting inquiry into a specific allegation against a specified Minister, past or present. Such a term is, we think, sufficient for the present circumstances.
P. DURACK Attorney-General
M. H. BYERS Solicitor-General 15 April 1982
SUBJECT: STATEMENT REGARDING ALLEGATIONS MADE IN AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENT RE C.I.A. INVOLVEMENT WITH NUGAN HAND BANK

1. In response to queries from the Associated Press and the United Press International regarding recent questions raised in the Australian Parliament, the Public Affairs Division of CIA issued the following statement on March 26, 1982.
BEGIN TEXT:

The Opposition Labor Party has produced documents alleging narcotics links between the collapsed Nugan-Hand Bank and the CIA. There are also resurgent charges that CIA engaged in operations against the Labor Government in Australia several years ago. Comment: The Agency rarely comments on such allegations but in this case we emphatically deny these charges; the CIA has not engaged in operations against the Australian Government, has no ties with Nugan-Hand and does not involve itself in drug trafficking.
END TEXT.
2. Thus far there appears to have been no/no press reaction to this statement in the U.S. Haig.
UNCLASSIFIEDSTATE 89264

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the statement.

speech.speaker: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak to the motion. The Opposition finds the statement which has just been put down by Senator Peter Baume quite inadequate in respect of the problems that exist concerning the Nugan Hand organisation. We believe-there is empirical evidence to sustain our view-that the Nugan Hand organisation is one of the most insidious groups that has developed in Australian political and social life in the post-War years. If it had not been for the strenuous efforts of the Opposition in the Parliament or for the sterling work of the National Times in particular-the work of Brian Toohey and Marian Wilkinson-the sordid story of Nugan Hand would have remained untold and unknown.

speech.para: In recent weeks, as a result of documents that have become available to the Opposition, it has become clear that this organisation has been playing a subversive and nefarious role in Australian political and economic life and that it has exercised influences far in excess of the normal activities of a trading organisation. As a result of Mr Fraser's attempts to overcome the difficulties in which the Government finds itself in respect of the allegations that have been made concerning Nugan Hand both inside and outside the Parliament the Opposition finds the Government's response completely and utterly inadequate. Consequently this ministerial statement is nothing more than an attempt at a superficial approach to the problem that exists concerning this organisation. For example, it recognises that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, has indicated a strong preference for the establishment of a new royal commission. We believe that the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force into Drug Trafficking were completely and utterly unable to do the sort of job that was necessary. The Government states that all it intends to do, on the advice of its law officers, is to extend the terms of reference of the Royal Commission to cover allegations of Nugan Hand's involvement in drug dealing beyond those associated with the Clark group. Of course, that shows how narrow the original terms of reference were as they dealt substantially with Terence Clark and his association with Mr Asia. The Government now at least accepts the fact that it should go beyond that . The Government further states:
Nugan Hand's laundering of money, and association with organised crime;
Interference with earlier investigation of Nugan Hand.

Of course the Government is forced into this position as Mr Hayden, in a substantial contribution in the House of Representatives, and I several weeks ago in this place, indicated by reading from documents that came from the former Federal Narcotics Bureau that the Government knew as far back as 1973 that an organisation associated with Nugan Hand required some investigation. But it was not brought to the attention of the Government until October 1975 when the Narcotics Bureau reported. Honourable senators should have no illusions as that was only a couple of weeks before the coup in which Kerr and Fraser were involved in bringing down the Whitlam Government.

There is abundant evidence in the material and the documents that are available to the Opposition to show that the terms of reference should deal with at least another eight or 10 issues rather than limit them to those three that the Government has finally been forced to concede. For example, it does not deal with tax evasion and currency manipulation-allegations that have been made in the newspapers. It does not deal with the association of Nugan Hand, and those connected with that organisation, with law enforcement agencies. It does not deal with the infiltration of political parties or with that organisation's involvement with other intelligence agencies including our own. It does not deal with the problems that this company had with its foreign links. It does not deal with the allegations made as recently as only a month ago in the National Times about the Nugan-Mafia link. It does not deal with gun running, an involvement which a number of newspaper articles have shown that this organisation had. It does not deal with the involvement of Nugan Hand directors with some of our respectable banks and with other so-called respectable business leaders in our community.

talk.start.para: —It does not prevent the inquiry from doing these things, does it?

—With respect, Senator, we do not believe that the inquiry is wide enough. We are still insisting-as Mr Hayden has insisted-that a royal commission should be set up to inquire into all of the aspects and the activities of this Nugan Hand organisation. Yet we are asked to agree to those three simple additions and not these other areas which have been covered very considerably in a series of articles in the National Times and the Sydney Morning Herald over the last two or three years.

speech.para: If we look at an article in the National Times of 21 February of this year written by Brian Toohey and Marian Wilkinson we find:
The story of the investigation of Nugan Hand is one of timidity alternating with dissembling at the highest levels of government.

The evidence of involvement by the 'dirty tricks' side of American intelligence in Nugan Hand is overwhelming. Yet Australian authorities have frequently refused to investigate the potential breaches of our espionage laws.
The article goes on to make this allegation:

Early last year the task force supplied ASIO with a list of Nugan Hand personnel suspected of having intelligence involvements. The then head of ASIO, Judge Woodward, replied on May 21 in a letter marked Top Secret.
Woodward said that ASIO knew of only two people on the list related to the intelligence world. One was the former head of the CIA, Bill Colby, while he said another, whom he refused to identify--

Of course, the Central Intelligence Agency in the United States of America stated in a communication from the United States Embassy that it had nothing to do with the overthrow of the Whitlam Government in 1975 and had nothing to do with Nugan Hand. Yet this Government, which is supposed to be concerned about protecting our independent position in world affairs and is supposed to be concerned about criminality and subversion in our country is prepared to accept the CIA's refusal to admit its involvement. Does anybody in this Parliament, anybody on any side of politics, anyone in the community at large, really believe that the Central Intelligence Agency will admit to any espionage? It never does until it is drawn before the United States Congress where, if one reads the testimonies of those investigations, one will find that the CIA has lied, bribed and murdered influential government figures all over the world. This is seen in the testimonies of the heads of the organisation which was brought before the Bar of the American Parliament. Yet the Australian Government accepts the word of the CIA that it was not involved and has not been involved.

Is the CIA not concerned, for example, about the American bases that are in Australia? Has it not got an interest in them and, does it not therefore play a part in attempting to influence governments, oppositions and public opinion about the use of these bases in the event of war? Anyone who believes that the CIA is not involved lives in cuckoo-land. Anybody, of course, who knows anything about politics knows that the Central Intelligence Agency is very much involved in Australian political affairs. It is involved in the trade union movement in our country. It is involved in my political party. It is involved in the National Country Party. It is involved in the Liberal Party. It is involved in every aspect of social life in our country. Anyone who believes otherwise does not understand the ways and the role of an intelligence gathering organisation.

When the Government suggests that it is not appropriate to establish a new commission it is not accepting its responsibilities. The Government refers to the fact the the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 March 1982 states that evidence was given to investigators that Nugan Hand supported and was used by persons and organisations across the political spectrum. Of course it was. Mr McDonald was involved with Nugan Hand. Mr Dowd came to Canberra three or four years ago. As a matter of fact I sat next to him in the dining room and heard him talking to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) about Nugan Hand. I did not know then what the details were. I heard him referring on several occasions to Nugan Hand and its involvement with the Liberal Party and other organisations. I know that it is involved also with my political party. I know, therefore, that it is a very subversive organisation. In fact, there is sufficient evidence in all of the articles in the National Times to prove the point to my satisfaction and certainly to the satisfaction of my party that there are people involved in the Nugan Hand organisation who were active members of the American Central Intelligence Agency. As we have seen in recent times as a result of Mr Hayden's debates in the House of Representatives and as we have seen in the last few days there are people in the various echelons of the Public Service who are prepared to make information available. The Government knows this. Therefore, it has backed down from the obstinate and scornful position that it occupied when Mr Hayden first raised this matter in the House of Representatives.
Just what did the National Times say in another article this year? The National Times states:

On February 12, 1972, Maurice Bernard Houghton stepped off Qantas Flight 575 at Sydney airport and was stopped by immigration officials. Houghton, a US citizen, had no re-entry visa. It had expired three months before.
But there was no problem. Houghton had two Australians he could call on for assistance. The immigration officer scribbled on his report: ''Vouched for by Mr Charody of Parkes Development--

We know that Parkes Development Pty Ltd and Sir Paul Strasser and other supporters of the Liberal Party have been very much involved in profit making in land development; obviously Charody was a sufficiently important person to be able to vouch for a person like Mr Houghton when he got off the plane-
and Mr Leo Carter ASIO''. Carter was the NSW head of ASIO (the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation).
Houghton's passport was stamped ''A''-he could stay in Australia as long as he wanted.

What sort of preferential treatment is given to a person like this gentleman who it was freely admitted in discussions that Brian Toohey had in the United States is a top operator of the Central Intelligence Agency? Let us look at the other people involved in the organisation-General Ed Black, Admiral Vasey, Admiral Yates, people involved in the Swiss/Pacific Bank Trust Co. which was later changed to the Nugan Hand Bank, all generals who fought in the Vietnam war, all generals who have had association with the American intelligence organisation. Of course, it is interesting that Michael John Hand, who is the other part of Nugan Hand, was a United States citizen who came to Australia and was naturalised. We see this American influence in this organisation.

What does the Australian Narcotics Bureau say? It is not included in the terms of reference. That is why I suggested that the CIA's involvement with the Narcotics Bureau should be one of the issues it would certainly be essential to consider if there were to be any proper inquiry into this organisation. Brian Bates said in 1978:
I desire that this Bureau should not for the time being engage in any active external inquiries into this matter.

That is, of Nugan Hand. That quote is from a letter sent to the Commander of the Eastern Region with copies to the Commander, Southern Region, C.I. (N.E.), C.I. (I.E.). I do not know what those abbreviations mean. I gather they are some abbreviations for organisations within the Bureau. The letter continued:

. . . I wish this to remain purely an Intelligence gathering and holding matter, oversighted from Canberra by Mr Haydock-Wilson, OLIA, to whom subsequent information reports connected wih the matter should be directed by Regions.
Will you please, therefore, ensure that, until further notice from me, no active external inquiries are embarked upon in relation to this matter . . .

We have another bit of paper from the Narcotics Bureau, again addressed to the Commander of the Eastern Region which is headed 'Subject: Nugan Hand Ltd. Suspect principles of heroin importations'. When Mr Hayden raised this matter in the House of Representatives he was taunted and criticised by the Government, particularly by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) who suggested that he was on some sort of witch hunt. Now the Government is being forced to concede that there is substance in the release of these documents which are available. This document puts the finger right on the question of drug dealing. It states:

The original information that Frank Nugan and Michael Hand were financing the importation of heroin was received on 3.5.77 and is contained in folios 1 and 3. Preliminary enquiries showed that Nugan Hand Ltd and a number of its associates: Leslie Collins, Robert Pike, John Norton, Graham Dempsey had come to the notice of the Narcotics Bureau in October 1975 (folios 30 and 31). Both Nugan and Hand travel extensively throughout South East Asia and Australia.
2. Nugan Hand Ltd, is supposed to be a merchant bank--
Nugan Hand had very close associations with merchant banks in our country-I will not name the banks; that will obviously come out in due course--

with a turnover in 1976-77 of $220 million. A BCI check shows that as at 12.7.77 Nugan Hand had made seven importations from Hong Kong and China, five being canned foods, one of furniture and one of golf clubs and balls.
There is a number of other documents. The one to which I have referred is signed by Phillip Bailey and is dated 14 November 1977. It states:

If Nugan Hand Ltd, is involved in the drug business it is most likely as either a behind the scene financier of drug importations or as a means of laundering the money made from drug sales. The second possibility should take into account the information received on folio 65.

There is no doubt, as we have found in respect of the unfortunate happenings involving two Ministers, that things are going on in departments which require a great deal of investigation. We are far from satisfied that the extended terms of reference will in anyway lead to an unravelling of the web of conspiracy that is clearly part of the Nugan Hand organisation.

We find it difficult to understand, for example, the treatment given to Mr Volkman who was formerly employed by the Bureau of Customs. The Attorney-General instituted proceedings against a number of former officers of the Bureau of Customs. The matter was dealt with in the Court of Petty Sessions in Sydney more than 18 months ago. Mr Nash found that there was no case to answer. Mr Volkman had suggested in discussions with fellow officers that a cover-up was taking place in respect of Nugan Hand. One is therefore entitled to ask why the Government is persecuting Mr Volkman to the extent that there is now an ex- officio indictment against him and four or five other people. It will involve a hearing of six or seven weeks in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. The maximum penalty is $1,000. That seems to us to indicate a degree of vindictiveness and an attempt to get square with some officers who have suspected the involvement of Nugan Hand and who have given information over the years to various persons in their organisation about what they believe the Nugan Hand organisation has been doing.
The OLIA summary No. 2 on Nugan Hand states:
2. During the period covered by this summary, four significant points/events are noted:
(a) Nov. 1977, Mr Dowd MLA was contacted by a Mr Peter WILCOX, and WILCOX was subsequently debriefed by this Bureau . . .
(b) Nov. through Dec. 1977, there was significant press reporting mainly of an adverse nature upon the NUGAN/HAND companies, as distinct from the NUGAN group based on Griffith, N.S.W.
I emphasise the distinction between the Nugan Hand companies and the Nugan group based on Griffith in New South Wales. The summary continues:
(c) Jan. 1978, James McCRUDDEN, a solicitor, alleged drug trafficking involvement by the NUGAN/HAND interests. (This information may have come from 'D ' Investigator VOLKMAN.)
He is the very person to whom I have referred who has been penalised and punished to a point where one wonders what the Government's objective is. The summary continues:
(d) Feb. 1978, registered informant 2010 starts providing information in relation to NUGAN/HAND and their possible involvement in drug trafficking.

One is entitled to ask on the basis of this evidence which is in the hands of a government agency why we restricted the Royal Commission headed by Mr Justice Stewart to dealing with drug trafficking, Mr Terence Clark and Mr Asia. Why was it not at the outset a royal commission into drug trafficking? I understand that we in the Parliament all have a common position, that is, we want to eradicate drug trafficking and corruption of our police forces and citizens that is so much synonymous with the drug movement in our country. All political parties have expressed that point of view. The information I am talking about was released in 1978 before the Stewart Royal Commission was established. Yet the Government-I say, delib- erately-narrowed the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission to deal with only one aspect of what is clearly a major criminal activity in this country.
The summary further states:

3. During this time the Bureau, both in Canberra and in Sydney, has consciously limited its investigations in this matter to background checks of an overt nature. Checks have of necessity been made in response to the points/events which have arisen during the period . . .
The summary details a number of other aspects which I do not think are relevant to this debate. Interestingly enough, at the bottom of the page, it states:
In Sydney-checks re biodata/identification of HOUGHTON (first-mentioned in this context by WILCOX).

Mr Houghton is the person whose status was accepted by our officers at Mascot Airport on the say so of some of our leading business and Australian Security Intelligence Organisation representatives in Sydney. One can say only that this attempt by the Government to extend the terms of reference to three other matters is nothing more than an attempt to whitewash the involvement of the Nugan Hand organisation in drugs, intelligence and political activities in this country. We do not accept the Government's assurance that it is satisfied as a result of statements made by the United States Government that there is no connection between the CIA and Nugan Hand. We do not accept the statements made by the Central Intelligence Agency itself that it was not involved in some of the nefarious activities that led to the overthrow of the Whitlam Government. We do not believe that it is sufficient to endorse the proposed reference by the task force, which deals with the activities of Murray Stewart Riley, Harry Wainwright and other related persons, to include relevant information concerning drug importation routes, unregistered gaol visits-who gives a damn about unregistered gaol visits-avoidance of the preventative screen by corruption and the sale and purchase of property. That is not what Mr Hayden and I have been saying about Nugan Hand. We believe that the Australian people, the Parliament and certainly the Australian Labor Party will not be satisfied until there is a royal commission into all the activities of the persons involved as well as the organisation known as Nugan Hand.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: -The Australian Democrats welcome the extension of the terms of reference for the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking under Mr Justice Stewart. However, it seems that the extension of the terms of reference, whilst covering crime and drug dealing, does not do what the statement incorporated in Hansard by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) seems to imply. Page 3 of the statement reads:

speech.para: The Government intends, however, that the extended terms of reference will be wide enough to allow the Commission to investigate Nugan Hand links with any organisation.
That sentence is, in the next sentence, modified in such a way, I believe, as to be unacceptable to the large proportion of Australian citizens. The statement reads:

The Commonwealth has always taken the view that all persons involved in criminal activities affecting Australia, regardless of whether they are members of any organisation, should be thoroughly investigated . . .

I believe that there is now within Australia general acceptance that all citizens want to know whether any ex-territorial organisations were involved in interference with the governance of this country and political parties, whether it involved drug trafficking, criminal activities or anything else. Therefore, the notion that we should investigate Nugan Hand only in relation to drug dealing, the laundering of money and other such areas is a severe limitation on the Commission's terms of reference and it is unacceptable to the majority of Australians.
Debate interrupted.
