talk.start.para: —Tonight I wish to voice concern about the electronic media's coverage of the Victorian State elections on the night the results came through. I do not do this in a partisan way because many of the Liberal scrutineers whom I talked to in the two weeks after the State election similarly voiced criticism of the absolutely pathetic coverage that that election result received on the night of the election. It is true to say that the commercial channels gave it very scant coverage. All three commercial stations gave the election half an hour's coverage at 10.30 on election night, four and a half hours after the polls closed. I do not think that is a coincidence. Either it occurred because the stations believe that that is when the ratings trail off and the second rate advertising should come on or there was a conspiracy between the three commercial stations and they said: 'None of us will break ranks. We will not give it any coverage. We will all go on with our normal commercial shows'. On the night of the election all they did from 7. 20 p.m. onwards was have two or three two-minute crossovers to the tally room when they informed the electorate of what the result would be. The regrettable thing was that in the first two crossovers all the stations predicted the wrong result. I daresay that if we had had a more extensive coverage by the commercial stations it would have given the stations more time to justify their wrong predictions. I should add that there was one exception, of which we in Victoria are proud, in that Bob Hawke predicted the result on the commercial channels two hours after the polls closed.

speech.para: However, my real beef tonight is with the coverage given by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I am not an ABC basher. I have a high regard for that organisation. But I would have thought that it was its duty to give the election some sort of coverage. Apart from a couple of small crossovers, there was a section from 8 p.m. to 8.20 p.m. and a final one at 10.30 p.m., which was a half hour coverage, in which it failed to interview the new Premier or the outgoing Premier. To get its coverage the ABC stuck a camera over the back of about 50 reporters. It was a really pathetic coverage.

The radio coverage did not on one occasion give a seat by seat call. People from other States would realise that the ABC radio coverage usually gives at least one call of the board to let people know the results. The television coverage by the ABC, when it was on air, was nothing short of pathetic. Garry Hutchinson, one of the journalists from the Melbourne Age, said that the coverage of certain electorates was universally trite, irrelevant and just prevented viewers from looking at the numbers. The ABC employed the services of a computer on the night. It was a marvellous computer! It did not work. People were running to members of the Australian Labor Party saying: 'What is the result in this seat?' The moment we gave it to them they fed it into the computer and that was the result which came up. However, I must congratulate the ABC's political expert, Mr Victor Prescott, for predicting a Labor victory at 9. 30 p.m. on election night. Three and a half hours after the polls closed this expert was able to discern a small swing to the Labor Party that would put it in government. The proverbial Blind Freddie could have seen at 8.30 p.m. what the election result would be. This is not the first time it has happened with the ABC's expert political coverage.

I remember in 1977, when the Liberal Party resoundingly defeated us in the Federal poll, at 10.10 p.m. the same individual detected a trend towards the Government being re-elected. I should have thought that the ABC would take care to engage someone who knew what he was talking about. I raise this matter tonight because on 15 May there will be a State election in Tasmania and there will be State elections in South Australia and Western Australia within the next 12 months. It is to be hoped that the people in those States will get a decent coverage of the State election results through the ABC. I do not believe that it would be such a poor rating program. No matter what the commercial channels do, I think the ABC has a duty to give those State elections a proper coverage.

speech.speaker: Martyr Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I will not detain the Senate long because most honourable senators already know how I feel about the matter I wish to raise. I wish to express total abhorrence at the decision of Mr Justice Helsham, the Chief Judge in Equity in New South Wales, which has condemned to death a totally innocent little human being. This little person, if not wanted by his or her closest relatives, was wanted by others who were prepared to love and care for him or her. I wonder whether His Honour wore a black cap when he handed down the death sentence. He joins those paragons of 'Jeffreys' justice in recent years-Their Honours Judges Levine and Menhennitt; Their Honours indeed!- who are responsible for the disgracefully loose interpretations of abortion law. These men have opened the door to what now can only be described as mass killing of hundreds of thousands of innocent little Australians in the womb.

speech.para: Of course, State governments permit the killing and perhaps the one in New South Wales even encourages it. Federal Governments fund it, newspaper editorials support it and radical women's groups rejoice in it, but it is still wrong. They are fundamentally mistaken. The paradox in this country today is that the killing of whales and the destruction of the environment are criminal offences whilst our species-that is, human beings in the womb-are now destroyed almost at whim. The law, instead of protecting the helpless innocents, seems to me to use its full majesty to destroy them. Today, as part of that law process, we should be in mourning for a little unnamed innocent who would undoubtedly, if asked, have opted for life.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise matters which are contained in the documents tabled in the Senate today principally because it was my understanding that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) was prepared to allow this matter to be debated at a later hour this day but for some reason that arrangement was not put into effect. I wish to do so because I think there is a relationship to matters I have raised in respect of the Nugan Hand organisation. One cannot but be disturbed at the attempts being made by certain people in the bureaucracy, in the Bureau of Customs, to cover up the material that is contained in the documents relating to the importation of a colour television set by the Hon. M. J. R. MacKellar. I thought that I had read all the newspaper articles on this issue, which has been with us since Friday of last week. My impression, having read those articles, was that Mr Moore, the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, had been misinformed by his Department. I do not resile from that conclusion except that it could well be that he was not informed by his Department and, in fact, was deliberately misinformed of the events that began to unfold in October of last year. I formed the impression then that Mr MacKellar was the person principally-

—Mr President, I understand Senator Gietzelt's dilemma and his distress that the matter did not come on for debate. However, I believe that he is directly breaching the Standing Orders by raising in the adjournment debate a matter which is on the Notice Paper. I am trying to obtain from Senator Sir John Carrick some information on the assurances he gave in order to give a proper response to Senator Gietzelt. I believe it is not within the Standing Orders to go back to the substance of those matters in the adjournment debate. I do not raise this point of order with any rancour.

—I was on the verge of suggesting to the honourable senator that he would not be within the Standing Orders if he were to debate any matter which is on the Notice Paper and which is still open for debate in this chamber. Standing Order 419 spells this out fairly clearly. Senator Gietzelt may respond to Senator Peter Baume's comments and mine if he wishes.

—I was not attempting to respond to what Senator Sir John Carrick, Senator Evans and Senator Grimes said because I appreciated that that would be transgressing Standing Orders. However, I submit that the tabling of the document is a matter that can be debated on the day on which it is done.

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —The Senate is now on the adjournment. There is a difference. As I understand it, today the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who is present in the chamber now, gave a clear undertaking to open the subject for debate.

interject.para: Is that correct, Mr Leader? I have just stated my understanding of your statement to the Senate today. You made it perfectly clear that the subject will be called on for debate in this chamber.

talk.start.para: —May I clarify the position, Mr President?
—Yes.

—The Senate will recall that today I said deliberately that I would adjourn the debate until later today or perhaps until tomorrow and that I would discuss with the leaders of the various parties what would be a convenient arrangement. I understand the convenient arrangement, as suggested by the Opposition, is that the debate will be called on tomorrow. That I have agreed to. In fact, the debate will be called on tomorrow. It will be a full debate. It will be conducted completely in the terms of the undertaking that I gave today, that is, that we would adjourn the debate until either later today or until tomorrow. After discussion it became utterly clear that it was not possible to hold the debate today. I repeat the assurance that following the approach of members of the Australian Labor Party and their suggestion that it would be convenient to hold the debate tomorrow, the matter will be scheduled for a full debate tomorrow.

—Are we talking about the debate which was initiated by Senator Sir John Carrick as a result of ministerial arrangements, the subject matter of which he said would be dealt with at a later hour this day?

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Senator, papers were also tabled today which were included in the subject matter for debate. That is a matter to which the Leader of the Government in the Senate has already referred. Standing Order 419 spells out the situation very clearly. I will just read one part. Whilst the Standing Order deals with digression from the subject matter, it goes on to say that no senator shall:

interject.para: . . . anticipate the discussion of any subject which appears on the Notice Paper.

In other words, once a paper has been tabled in this place it belongs to the Senate for debate. It has been made clear that there will be a debate on the matter. It is very much a borderline case, Senator, but I suggest to you that unless you have singular points to make rather than debating the matter, it would be better if you were to defer your remarks until the opportunity comes up tomorrow.

talk.start.para: —I am--
—I suggest that you show courtesy to the Chair, Senator.

—I am in an awkward position in that I will not be here tomorrow, Mr President. That is why I was seeking an opportunity to make some comments. The documents were tabled. My understanding was that the Leader of the Government said that matter would be debated later this day. I know that there was some crossfire over the table, but I then did some work on the document. I find now that as a result of some change in arrangements one is not able to persist with the examination of the documents before us. Of course, I will find myself in exactly the same position in the adjournment debate tomorrow evening because the matter will have been discussed again tomorrow, and the arrangements for Thursday will also prevent me from speaking. The sort of arrangements that have been agreed to will prevent me from making the contribution that I wish to make on this matter.

—I say also that Senator Grimes today moved a motion for the Senate to take note of the papers and the statement. That is a positive motion which is now before the Senate chamber. Standing Orders curtail what can be debated. I sympathise with you, Senator Gietzelt. You may have prepared a very sound speech but circumstances may prevent you from giving it until tomorrow.

speech.speaker: Georges Sen G.

talk.start.para: —I do not want my remarks to come into conflict with the provisions of Standing Order 419. The ruling is, of course, correct. The problem today is that a document was suddenly tabled and only a certain number of copies were distributed. I think the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) suggested that we should have the debate later today when documents were fully available, et cetera. I thought that was the correct procedure to adopt. Unfortunately what has happened now is that the program has expired. We did not get to the matter, which puts Senator Gietzelt in a very awkward position. I take it that he is the shadow Minister responsible for this area, that the matter falls within the area for which he has responsibility. So he has some difficulty. I take it that his difficulty will be taken into consideration when the debate takes place.

speech.para: I just say that the sudden emergence of such a document puts the Senate at a disadvantage. I do not know whether on this occasion the two hours notice had been given. If it had been there would possibly have been a fuller debate at the time. In any case, the two hours notice may have been given on this occasion, but subsequently another very important document was tabled, relating to the Nugan Hand case. The Minister who tabled that document in the Senate indicated that the two hour requirement had not been fulfilled.

talk.start.para: —I sought leave and the Senate could have refused me leave on that basis.

—I know. We did not refuse the Minister leave because the document was important but we are put at a considerable disadvantage. All I am saying is that I think in the future we ought to get back to that procedure, even if it does inhibit the Government in its desire-I was going to say 'haste'- of bringing the problems before the Senate as soon as possible. I think it is far better to stay with the rules-that is, to give the two hours notice to the Opposition-and also to make certain that when a document is tabled in the Senate every honourable senator receives a copy. It may be that at that moment an honourable senator may want to raise a particular problem. He is entitled to do so and, what is more, he should be able to do so. That is why I have just entered the debate. There is no way in which we can satisfy Senator Gietzelt's requirement tonight because of the Standing Order, but I say that we did get a clear indication from the Leader of the Government that we would have the debate today. I come back to the other problem. I suggest that the Government should let the party leaders on the Opposition side have documents two hours before they are tabled so that the leaders can make the necessary arrangements for some extended debate at the time. As it was, we had two of-the-cuff performances, both good, by Senator Grimes on one matter and by Senator Gietzelt on the other. But that left the debate up in the air and no one else was able to participate.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: — Several honourable senators have contributed to the adjournment debate tonight. I shall take Senator Gietzelt's matter first because I should like to clear up any misunderstanding in the light of what Senator Georges said. The two-hour rule applies to situations in which honourable senators wish to seek leave to make statements. If at any time a Minister wants to make a statement the rule is that two hours notice should be provided to those from whom leave is to be sought. The same requirement does not apply to documents that are to be tabled. The question of courtesy, of course, involves us in giving what notice we can, but the documents which were tabled today by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Sir John Carrick) were documents of great public interest and of great importance and it was considered that the moment they became available they should be placed before the Parliament. I think that was a proper course to take with the documents as was the course that was taken to expedite a debate. In the event, the debate was not brought on today but Senator Sir John Carrick said that it will occur tomorrow.

speech.para: In relation to Senator Martyr's speech, I take it that no comment is required from the Government. The only point I would make-the honourable senator has not remained in the chamber-is that I thought the reference to Mr Justice Helsham went very close to contravening the Standing Orders. I think that was a little unfortunate.

In relation to Senator Robert Ray's speech, I am not aware of exactly what the coverage was of the Victorian State election. I have no reason to doubt it was as Senator Robert Ray said. I take it he was not watching all the channels or listening to the radio simultaneously . I take it he has heard this from people who were monitoring the electronic media.

talk.start.para: —It is in the television program guide, actually. We knew about it beforehand from the television program guide and they stuck to it.

—Senator Robert Ray said he had prior knowledge. Part of the difficulty, of course, is that a State election, even one as important to Senator Robert Ray's party as that particular election was, is not of the same importance as a national election and it attracts a different degree of media interest and media coverage. In New South Wales, of course, we were sorry that a by-election last week did not receive greater media coverage. I guess that is the way of the world. I am not willing to agree with the honourable senator that those who participated were necessarily incompetent or anything else. I am sure that the commentators made their decisions as and when they could. I have always enjoyed watching Victor Prescott. As often as not he has been saying things about my party and how it is faring on a particular evening. The fact that he did not make a decision until 9.30 p.m. could be just natural caution.

speech.para: I recall in 1974 when I was first elected to this place there was a commentator then on one of the television channels, the same commentator who was applauded by Senator Robert Ray tonight, Mr Robert Hawke. He started the evening full of enthusiam for what the result was going to be and became less and less certain as that evening went on. As honourable senators may recall at the end of the evening he was not at all certain. I do think it is possible to be cautious with very good reason. The real point that Senator Robert Ray was putting to the Senate was that he hoped that in relation to the forthcoming State elections in Tasmania, the immediate one coming up in Tasmania and the ones to come in South Australia and Western Australia, the Australian Broadcasting Commission would give some consideration to adequate coverage of those events. I think that was the point he was really asking me to take to the Minister whom I represent. That I will undertake to do and put to him the points which have been raised by the honourable senator.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

question.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that some teachers who applied to teach in Zimbabwe, under Commonwealth Government sponsorship through the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, have had difficulties in obtaining leave without pay from their respective State Education Departments.
(2) Can the Minister ascertain whether any teachers were refused leave without pay and, if so why.

(3) Can the Minister say why the advertisements seeking teachers for Zimbabwe appeared so late in the school year, and why contact with State Education Departments was inadequate, leading to the leave without pay problems outlined in (1) above.

(4) Will the Minister investigate, in consultation with State Education Departments, the provision of automatic leave without pay for teachers who are selected to teach abroad under Commonwealth sponsored arrangements to ensure that this unfortunate situation does not arise again.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am aware that some teachers offered positions by the Government of Zimbabwe to teach in Zimbabwe have had difficulties in obtaining leave without pay from their respective State Education Departments.
(2) I understand that some teachers have been refused leave without pay by their Education Departments, but I am no aware of the reasons underlying such decisions.

(3) The agreement between the Australian and Zimbabwe Governments under which Australia provides financial assistance to enable the Government of Zimbabwe to recruit Australians for service in that country places full responsibility for recruitment in the hands of that Government. I have no evidence which suggests that the timing of the campaign was necessarily the reason for the teachers being refused leave without pay.

(4) As a result of experience gained in their first campaign, the Zimbabwe Government has consulted with the Australian Development Assistance Bureau in relation to a subsequent recruitment campaign. The Bureau has written to State Education Departments to seek their co-operation, including on the issue of leave without pay. The Zimbabwe recruitment teams have also taken up this issue directly with individual State departments.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

question.para: (1) Have the guidelines governing the admission of overseas students to Australian secondary schools been liberalised.
(2) Were overseas students previously only able to come to Australia for Year 12 studies at secondary schools.
(3) Have some private, or independent schools, received up to 50 applications for Year 10, 11 and 12 places for children from Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong.

(4) What provision will be made for supporting these young people who are accepted into Australian Schools, given that the Regional Offices of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau (ADAB) are scheduled to be closed.

(5) Will the Government reconsider its decision to close the regional ADAB offices, given that a considerable influx of youngsters is planned, many of whom will not speak fluent English and who will be isolated from their families at a crucial age.
(6) Do overseas secondary school children coming to Australia to study have to pay fees to the Government.
(7) How many applications have been received for visas for overseas secondary school children wishing to study in Australia.
(8) Have any additional funds been made available to Australian schools and tertiary institutions for the support of young overseas students.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Entry in the past was limited mainly to senior secondary level students from developing countries in our region where educational facilities were assessed as being inadequate. Overseas students may now be admitted for study from all countries at junior as well as senior secondary level, although entry at junior secondary level is in the main confined to students attending boarding schools because of the need to ensure the provision of adequate supervision.
(2) As indicated above, entry was previously limited in the main to the senior secondary level. Entry was permitted at Year 11, but the majority of overseas students entered directly into Year 12.

(3) Details of the numbers of applications received by non-government schools are not available, but the schools have indicated that numbers of inquiries and applications received by them have increased significantly in recent months.

(4) and (5) The Government recently decided, following a review by the Public Service Board, that the ADAB Regional Offices should continue to carry out their present functions, which include the provision of welfare counselling services to all overseas students whether sponsored or private from developing countries and assisting co-ordinating committees to provide a community-based welfare program. All private students must have a financial guarantor who is responsible for all costs connected with their travel and stay in Australia. Junior secondary students may only be admitted to boarding schools or to day schools when satisfactory private arrangements have been made for their accommodation and supervision.

(7) Separate statistics on visa applications by level of study are not maintained. Visa issue statistics for the 1980/81 financial year show that 2165 visas were issued to secondary students (including some 700 exchange students). It is expected that around 3,500 secondary students will be admitted in 1982 ( including an estimated 1,000 exchange students).

(8) No additional funds have been made available to the Commonwealth Schools Commission or to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, intended specifically for the support of overseas students. However, under Commonwealth funding arrangements for schools, overseas students are counted for enrolment purposes in determining the level of general recurrent grants paid to non- government schools. Commonwealth funds are also provided to government schools for general purposes and overseas students in those schools may also benefit from those general purpose funds.

question.speaker: Colston Sen M.A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

question.para: Were Queensland Post Offices closed on 4 January 1982; if so-
(a) why; and
(b) why did Australia Post not care about providing a service to businesses and individual customers on that date.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Yes.

Throughout Australia, Australia Post staff are entitled to the holiday traditionally granted to Australian public sector employees between Christmas and New Year, usually observed on the day following the Boxing Day holiday.

Prior to 1981, except where special arrangements were made, post offices closed on that holiday and mail deliveries were not provided. As a result, in some years, the public has been without postal services for up to five consecutive days (including weekends) over the Christmas period.

In March 1981, Australia Post held discussions with retail trading organisations to ascertain the day on which they considered Australia Post should observe the Authorised Holiday to minimise customer inconvenience. Because the day following the New Year Holiday is generally a quieter trading day, the view was that Australia Post should observe the holiday on that day.

The Australian Postal Commission subsequently decided that, as from 1981, Australia Post should observe the holiday on a day which will limit the period without postal services to four consecutive days (including weekends). Generally , the holiday will be observed on the day following the New Year Holiday, as was the case for 1981.
In Queensland, counter services were available on 4 January 1982 at the Brisbane GPO and also at a small number of non-official post offices operated in conjunction with a private business.

question.speaker: Colston Sen M.A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

question.para: (1) What are the details of the working holiday makers scheme including:
(a) the eligibility to participate in the scheme;
(b) the conditions applying and the period of stay permissable;
(c) the method of application to participate; and
(d) the way in which working holiday makers are able to apply for permanent residence in Australia.
(2) How many working holiday makers have arrived in Australia in:
(3) How many working holiday makers in each of these years have applied for permanent residence whilst in Australia and how many of those applications were successful.

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Young people, generally in the age group 18 to 25 years either single or married without children, who are citizens of countries with which Australia has working holiday arrangements-Ireland, Canada, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands and Japan-are eligible to participate in the scheme.
Provision exists also for the extension of the scheme to citizens of other countries who have outstanding qualities and a genuine interest in a working holiday in Australia.
(b) The following conditions apply:
employment must be incidental to the holiday purpose;
possession of a sound employment background or reasonable prospects of obtaining temporary employment to supplement holiday funds;
possession of a return ticket or sufficient funds to cover a return ticket;
possession of reasonable funds for normal maintenance purposes for the initial part of the proposed holiday period;
meet the health and character requirement for entry to Australia.

Generally visas issued to approved applicants authorise an initial stay in accordance with the period sought, however applicants may apply for an extension of stay up to a maximum period of twelve months.

(c) Anyone wishing to participate in the scheme should lodge their application at an Australian Government office overseas. An Australian official will then assess the application. The applicant may later be interviewed and counselled on casual job opportunities.
(d) A working holiday maker who is the holder of a valid temporary entry permit , may, upon payment of the fee of $125, apply for resident status under Section 6A (1) of the Migration Act 1958.

Eligibility for the grant of resident status is, under this Section, limited to those applicants able to obtain 35 points in each of Parts A and B of NUMAS, the same numerical migrant selection assessment system used at overseas posts. No credit is given for pre-arranged employment.
Applicants accumulating lower scores are to be refused except where consideration under Section 6A (1) (e) is appropriate, i.e. where there are strong compassionate or humanitarian factors presented.
In cases warranting approval, the usual health and character requirements have to be met.
(2) (a) 5,540 persons.
(b) 7,793 persons.
(c) 5,585 persons (January-June only).
(3) Although statistics of persons holding temporary resident visas who were granted residence are available, it is not possible to identify working holiday makers separately.

question.speaker: Colston Sen M.A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

question.para: (1) When was it determined to allow a rebate for an excess of concessional expenditure over the sum of $1,590.
(2) What would that figure be if it had increased in line with inflation.
(3) Why has this figure not been so increased.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The rebate for an excess of concessional expenditure over the sum of $1,590 stems from changes made to the personal income tax system by the previous Government in 1975-76, when a general tax rebate was introduced. At that time, all taxpayers were allowed a general tax rebate and a further rebate was allowed to those taxpayers whose concessional expenditure in total exceeded a given amount, initially $1,350. This scheme replaced the deduction that has previously been allowed for concessional expenditures.

In the financial year 1977-78, the present Government did away with the general rebate and introduced instead a very substantial zero-rated first step of the income tax scale. The commencing point for the additional rebate for ''excess'' concessional expenditure was set $100 below the level to which it had by then risen as a result of indexation of the general rebate.
(2) Since 1977-78, the standard rate personal income tax scale has been indexed by approximately 11.8 per cent. If the $1,590 had been indexed in line with the tax scale, it would now be $1,778.

(3) Indexation of the figure would have meant that fewer taxpayers could have obtained a concessional expenditure rebate, as expendiure levels between $1,590 and $1,778 would not have attracted a rebate, as they now do.

question.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

(2) Has any recommendation been made by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment to increase the budget by this amount to provide adequate research as described by Dr McMichael.
(3) Has any list of priorities in research covering an agreed list of endangered species of Australian birds, mammals, flowering plants and any other groups been drawn up by the department.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes, my attention has been drawn to the statement which was made in a paper presented at the Australian Academy of Science's symposium on the biology of rare and endangered species in Australia. This statement applied to research on animals rather than plants. Dr McMichael, who is an acknowledged expert on endangered species conservation, estimated that the research necessary to understand the biology of any one endangered species, to the extent necessary for the indentification of likely causes of decline in numbers and/or range, could not be undertaken for less than $100,000. He concluded that, in view of the number of endangered species, it was unlikely that sufficient funds would ever be available to adequately research all such species and that it would therefore be necessary to choose between them.

(2) The Department of Home Affairs and Environment is not a research organisation and has no budget for research on the causes and antidotes to the extinction of endangered species. Most research of this kind in Australia is undertaken by staff of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Wildlife Research; Commonwealth, State and Territory wildlife authorities; Museums and Herbaria; and University Zoology and Botany Departments. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service funds annual programs of research and surveys related to nature conservation including studies on endangered species. The budget approved for these programs in 1981-82 amounted to $255,000.

(3) A list of 94 endangered species of Australian mammals, birds and reptiles has been adopted by the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers. This list is currently being examined by a Working Group established by the Council to determine priorities for research and management programs. There is also another Working Group of the Council concerned with the listing of endangered species of plants.

question.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

question.para: (1) Was the United Nations Medal approved by the Australian Government for issue to, and wearing by, Australian troops who fought in the Korean War, in addition to the British-issued Korea Medal, despite a long established convention that no person should be granted more than one decoration for the same service; if so, why.
(2) Did the Australian Government accept the offer made by the South Vietnamese Administration to award the Vietnam Campaign Medal to all Australian servicemen who served in Vietnam; if so, why.
(3) Did the Greek Government make the Greek War Medal available to former members of the Australian forces in recognition of their contribution in the Greek campaign of 1941.
(4) Why was permission refused for the wearing of the Greek Medal in view of the fact that permission was given for the wearing of the United Nations and Korean Medals.

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Korea Medal was instituted by the Sovereign for Service in the Korean War and is accepted and worn in this light.

The United Nations Service Medal, Korea, is neither a British or a foreign award and is not provided for in traditional rules. It was established under the authority of the United Nations and accepted by member nations which participated in the Korean War.

The Korean War was the first action involving Australian troops in a United Nations Force. The United Nations Service Medal, Korea was the first such award made by the international body and conventions applying to foreign awards i.e. awards of other national entities are not seen as relevant in that context.

(2) The Australian Government sought and was given the permission by the Queen to accept the Vietnam Campaign Medal as a special case. The American, Korean and Thai Governments had accepted the Vietnamese offer and a refusal could have affected the morale of Australian troops then serving in operations in Vietnam.

(3) In 1979, the Australian Government received advice that by Presidential decree issued in Greece in 1978 eligibility to a Commemmorative Medallion which had been established in 1946 for members of Greek units which fought in Greece during World War II had been extended to foreign servicemen who served in Greece as members of the Allied Forces.

(4) British and Australian servicemen who served in Greece and Crete in 1941 were awarded the British 1939-45 Star in recognition of that service. It is a long standing convention in British and Australian honours and awards practice that no person should receive more than one award in recognition of the one act or service. None of the circumstances which applied to the Korea Medal, the United Nations Service Medal, Korea, or the Vietnamese Campaign Medal apply in the case of the Greek Commemorative Medallion and the considerations governing acceptance of these various medals cannot validly be compared.

answer.para: (1) Yes. The aircraft was located by a departmental aircraft engaged in photography of the search area for inclusion in the report of the investigation into the accident.
The wreckage was located on the flight planned track of the aircraft.

(2) Primary attention by way of complete saturation searching by rotary and fixed wing search aircraft, was given to a relatively small area which embraced the wreckage site. However, the density of the primary and secondary vegetation, in conjunction with the topography of the primary search area, is such that it is possible to hover directly over a search target without a sighting unless wreckage disturbed by fire or broken foliage. These conditions defy the effective use of aerial photography and other available electronic detection devices. No assistance was received from the emergency location beacon carried on this aircraft, which was found subsequently to have been completely destroyed on impact.

(3) No. The RAAF F111 aircraft photographed an area assigned by the Rescue Co- ordination Centre which did not include the accident site.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

question.para: What are the details of the protection measures imposed by the Queensland Government on the proposal to develop coal deposits at Redbank Plains near Ipswich, Queensland that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment claims are sufficient to protect environmental interests to the extent that an Environment Impact Statement would not be necessary.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Queensland Government, acting upon the recommendations of the Mining Warden , granted the Mining Lease in January 1982. Extensive conditions were imposed under the lease and many of these relate to the protection of the environment. The most significant of these are:
General Conditions The Lessee shall comply with the sludge abatement conditions as required by Section 60 (2) (a), (b) and (c) of the Mining Act 1968-1980.
The Lessee shall observe at all times the provisions of the Clean Waters Act 1971-1979 or any licenses issued under that Act as they relate to the Lessee or to the Lease.
The Lessee shall not permit mining or mining operations to interfere with the course or flow of the Woogaroo Creek.
The Lessee shall, unless otherwise approved, deposit all overburden and sludge within the boundaries of the Lease.
All stockpiles of wastes, products or topsoil remaining on the Lease area at the cessation of mining shall be disposed of by the Lessee in an approved manner .
The Lessee shall maintain the Lease area free of mining rubbish at all times.
The Lessee shall not use explosives on the Lease area other than in accordance with plan approved by the Minister.
The Lessee shall ensure that coal transport vehicles leaving the Lease area are fully covered by tarpaulins so that they are not likely to deposit coal on public roads.
The Lessee shall provide a sealed road for the passage of vehicles between the surface facilities of the mine and public roadways.
The Lessee shall ensure that no more flora or trees than is necessary are cleared from the Lease area and he shall maintain existing vegetation between the pits and neighbouring residential areas.
The surface facilities of the mine, including dangerous dams and openings shall be contained within suitable fencing or otherwise protected in an approved manner.

The Lessee shall regularly monitor the concentrations of dust and noise leaving the lease area and shall ensure that dust and noise levels are such that they will not be a nuisance at the location of residences adjacent to lease boundaries. Where the Minister requires additional precautions to be taken he shall so direct the Lessee who shall comply with such direction.
Open Cut Mining Conditions All open cut mining and rehabilitation in accordance with conditions 3.5 (a), (b), (c) and (d) shall be completed within two (2) years of commencement.
The area being mined and not rehabilitated in accordance with these conditions shall not exceed three (3) hectares unless otherwise approved.

Prior to the commencement of any mining on the Lease the Lessee shall submit to the Minister a plan of the Lease area marked in contours with vertical height intervals of not more than one (1) metre and the Lessee shall not mine on the Lease until such plan has been so submitted.

Prior to the commencement of mining of an area the Lessee shall remove and stack separately all the soil from that area which he is to disturb and the material stockpiled shall be conserved for use during the rehabilitation of the disturbed area and for no other purpose. For the purposes of this condition '' soil'' shall mean ''that material which is organically enriched or that material within 300 mm of the ground surface, whichever is the greater''.
Following the mining or disturbance of an area by open cut mining operations the Lessee shall:-
(a) return all stockpiles of overburden and sludge to the open cut;
(b) grade and contour the surface of the disturbed ground such that:-
(i) it conforms to the surrounding topography;
(ii) all drainage lines and waterways are reconstructed as near as practicable to the situation existing prior to mining; and
(iii) the contoured ground is made as stable as may be to the natural forces of erosion.
(c) return the soil, stockpiled and stored in compliance with condition 3.4., and spread such soil evenly over the contoured ground;
(d) sow the soil with such grass or pasture species as the Minister may approve ;
(e) plant tree seedlings in such numbers and in such locations as approved; and
(f) maintain the rehabilitated areas, and comply with the terms of any direction given by the Minister for the purposes of maintaining such rehabilitated areas, for the duration of the Lease.
The Lessee shall provide and maintain adequate drainage facilities on the Lease area to prevent water from any watercourse entering an open cut.

Neither the Lessee nor his agents or assigns shall conduct mining or transport operations on the Lease area before 6.30 a.m. nor after 5.30 p.m. on any working day. There shall be no mining or transport operations conducted on any Saturday, Sunday or Public Holiday.

talk.start.para: —On 25 August 1981 (Hansard, page 254) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning foreign ownership of Australian merchant banks. As part of my answer to the honourable senator's question, I undertook to seek, from the Treasurer, advice as to any action he might take to increase Australian equity in this industry.

answer.para: The Treasury has advised me that the following foreign investment policy requirements are designed to maintain and, over time, to increase Australian equity in the financial sector:

Proposals for the establishment of new merchant banks are approved, other than in very exceptional circumstances, only if there will be at least 50 per cent beneficial Australian equity and effective participation by way of at least shared Australian-foreign control of the new venture.

Proposals by foreign investors to acquire an interest in an existing merchant bank are closely examined, whether the shares are currently owned by Australian interests or are held by overseas interests, the procedures followed in each case being:

if the shares are currently owned by Australian interests, and the proposed sale to foreign investors thus involved a reduction in the level of Australian ownership, approval would be granted only in circumstances where it had been demonstrated that substantial benefits could be expected to accrue to Australia , taking account of the implications of the proposal for the financial sector. In practice, because merchant banks operating in Australia already provide a wide range of services, this is generally a difficult test to meet.

if the shares are currently owned by overseas interests then the proposed purchase by other foreign investors would not involve a reduction in the level of Australian ownership, and the proposal would normally be approved provided the Government was satisfied that the shares had first been offered to Australian investors and that no Australian investors were interested in acquiring them on commercial terms and conditions.

Merchant banks that were established with high levels of foreign ownership in the period prior to the introduction of the present foreign investment guidelines are encouraged, by way of the procedures mentioned above, to introduce or increase Australian equity participation. In addition, in the context of the Government's approval of certain proposals Australian equity has been required to be introduced within specified time periods. Apart from these procedures and the existence of Australian equity conditions remaining to be fulfilled in certain specific cases, however, there is no general requirement for merchant banks established prior to the introduction of the present foreign investment guidelines to introduce Australian equity.

answer.to.qwn.title: Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Meat Industry

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —On 10 March 1982 (Hansard, page 645), Senator Walsh asked me a question, without notice, concerning legal representation for the Minister for Primary Industry at the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Meat Industry. His question asked:

answer.para: (a) Is it a fact that the Minister for Primary Industry has been represented by legal counsel throughout the inquiry by the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry?
(b) If so, who engaged the barrister to represent Mr Nixon?
(c) How much is this costing and who is paying?
(d) Is there any benefit to the Commonwealth in this exercise, or is it a case of the Commonwealth footing a huge legal bill simply to keep yet another Country Party Minister out of trouble?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(a) Leave was granted by the Royal Commission to Mr R. J. Stanley to represent the Minister for Primary Industry, on 18 February 1982. The decision to seek leave was based on advice from my Department after consultation with the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor. The question of whether Counsel will continue to represent me throughout the inquiry is expected to be reviewed shortly.
(b) The Commonwealth Crown Solicitor.
(c) An amount of $75,000 is being sought in the Additional Estimates to cover the costs.

(d) It was decided to engage Counsel because it is essential that the substantial changes now being made to Commonwealth Meat Inspection be brought to the attention of the Royal Commission. The changes include establishment of an Export Inspection Service, new export legislation and regulations, amendments to the AMLC Act, tighter administrative controls, and follow-up to the Price Waterhouse Report. Counsel has been given firm instructions that this representation is not to protect any individual from examination or cross- examination that may be directed to establishing dishonesty or inefficiency.

talk.start.para: —On 10 March 1982 (Hansard, page 642) Senator Macklin asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice about copyright costs in schools.

answer.para: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government's intention to amend the Copyright Act 1968 was announced by the Attorney-General in June 1978. The following month, the Commonwealth and State Ministers for Education, meeting as the Australian Education Council, established a working party to advise them on the implications for schools.

In June 1979 the Attorney-General tabled a Copyright Amendment Bill, for public discussion. In September that year, the then Minister for Education strongly supported the AEC working party's submission that the arrangements proposed for recording school copying were too complex and costly, and asked the Attorney-General to delay the leglislation until a simpler system of record -keeping could be devised.
My understanding is that the Copyright Amendment Act eventually passed in September 1980 should be much easier for schools to work under, than the legislation originally proposed.
Nevertheless some administrative costs can be expected, in addition to royalty costs which may be incurred where schools reproduce copyright material for their classes under the new legislation.
It has been suggested to me that the Commonwealth should provide funds to offset these costs, and I have consulted the Attorney-General in this matter as the Minister responsible for copyright law.

The Commonwealth will not be providing extra funds specifically to assist schools or other institutions to meet copyright costs. The Commonwealth cannot accept the proposition that where a change in the copyright law is made and expense is incurred by a party in order to take advantage of new rights conferred, the Commonwealth should contribute specifically towards meeting that expenditure.

School funding is basically a matter for the State Governments and other bodies which operate schools. The Commonwealth, through its Schools Commission, provides these bodies with substantial additional funds, most of which are not designated for particular purposes. Where the Commonwealth's contribution to school funding is concerned, it is not the Government's policy that special funds should automatically be provided for every new cost incurred as a result of legislative or other changes.

If in due course the States choose to document cost increases arising from the changes to copyright law in their routine submissions to the Commonwealth Schools Commission, the Government will be in a position to decide whether or not those costs should influence the overall level of funds to be provided for schools by the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: —On 11 March 1982 (Hansard, page 691) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

answer.para: I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether she has seen reports that President Reagan has authorised covert operations against the Government of Nicaragua. What action has the Australian Government taken to inform the United States of America of Australia's concern about the situation which is developing in Latin America? Will the Government tell the United States firmly that it supports initiatives, such as those offered by the French and Mexican governments, that will lead to a political solution to the problems of this region? Will it further say that those solutions should be based on social and economic reforms?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government is aware of reports that President Reagan has authorised covert operations against the Government of Nicaragua. The United States Government is aware of the Australian Government's concern about the situation in Central America. I discussed this with Vice President Bush when I visited Washington last year. In August last year the French and Mexican Governments in a joint statement on El Salvador recalled that it was for the Salvadoran people to indicate a settlement process and appealed to the international community to work, particularly in the framework of the United Nations, in order that there might be reconciliation in El Salvador. In February this year the President of Mexico called for a process of negotiations to bring peace to El Salvador and to improve United States relations with Nicaragua and Cuba. He offered his services as a mediator. The Australian Government would be prepared to support any move for a political settlement which had the agreement of all the main parties to the conflict in El Salvador. The Government has welcomed the elections to be held in El Salvador on 25 March and expressed the hope that they will contribute to peace and reconciliation in El Salvador. The Government has noted and welcomes the fact that the United States has underlined the importance of economic and social reform in El Salvador and other countries of Central America. The recent announcement by President Reagan of a Caribbean Basin Economic Program with increased United States aid, trade and investment of US$350 million in direct economic assistance, is evidence of this. The Australian Government also accepts that the United States has taken a stand in the face of evidence of external support for left-wing guerilla movements operating inside El Salvador.

talk.start.para: —On 17 March 1982 (Hansard, page 854) Senator Sibraa asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Senate, the following question without notice:

answer.para: Is it true the Government is facing significant losses in revenue because of inadequate validation checks on excise collection? Does this arise from a report of an efficiency audit of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs? Did the Auditor-General estimate that the loss of revenue stemmed from doubtful accuracy of meters used to calculate revenue? Did this comment relate to losses claimed as occurring in oil refineries during transfers from refineries to depots or within depots? Finally, did the Auditor-General estimate that the loss of revenue which resulted is probably $10m a year?
The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In the Report of the Auditor-General on an Efficiency Audit of 'The Collection of Excise duties and deferred Customs duties by the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs', the Auditor-General did report specifically on petroleum products.

In the report the Auditor-General acknowledged that legitimate losses of petroleum products did occur because of their volatile nature. He explained that under present controls the Department relies upon checks of company records supported by physical investigations in determining dutiable quantities for the payment of revenue and that in relation to losses the Department accepts figures based upon previous performance patterns, unless they are abnormal, rather than technical analysis.
Under the present arrangements dutiable quantities are determined at the time of product entering home consumption from refineries or depots.

The Auditor-General in his report advocates the installation of independent meters for the measurement of dutiable quantities at the point of production within refineries as a means of validation of company records of total production and allowing greater departmental effort in assessing companies' claims for losses.

The Auditor-General did not refer to an estimated loss of $10m revenue a year. In this regard he said, 'The notional duty attaching to losses claimed as occurring in refineries, during transfers from refineries to depots, or within depots is of the order of $10m annually. Measurement of dutiable volume at the point of production and placing more onus on the companies to justify claims for losses would in view of this office, be more conducive to ensuring the collection in full of revenues due'.

The Department of Business and Consumer Affairs has commenced discussions with oil companies with a view to examining the cost-benefit and long-term technical implications of installing accurate flow measurement devices at the point of production in refineries.

answer.to.qwn.title: Prime Minister's Office: Advertisement for Secretary

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —In response to Senator Evans's question without notice of 18 March 1982 (Hansard, page 927), I undertook to refer to the Prime Minister the matters raised concerning the advertisement for his electorate secretary.

answer.para: The Prime Minister has provided the following further information:

The determination of staff numbers and the terms and conditions for staff of Ministers, including electorate secretaries, is a matter for the Government, not the Remuneration Tribunal. This has been the case since the Tribunal was established in 1973.

In my own case, because of the amount of time I necessarily spend in Canberra, and the amount of electorate correspondence that comes directly to Canberra, it is sensible for my electorate secretary to be Canberra based. The additional position of electorate assistant is based at Hamilton in my electorate.

There was an oversight in the wording of the advertisement, which I regret, but I am pleased to be able to say that this did not deter a number of men from applying for the position. Their applications will of course receive equal consideration with those of the female applicants.
